name: Compromise: External Brute Force Auths
description:
Successful authentication after multiple failed attempts from different external origin hosts to the same impacted host.

UTD
details: Use Case: An attacker knows a login id to a specific host and repeatedly attempts to authenticate using various passwords from different origin hosts in an attempt to mask the password guessing activity, and eventually successfully authenticates.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: External Brute Force Auths

commonEvent.name: AIE: Compromise: External Brute Force Auths

name: Attack: Failed Brute Force Auth
description:
Multiple failed authentication attempts from the same external origin host to the same impacted host, without seeing an authentication success.

UTD
details: Use Case : An attacker knows a login id to a specific host and repeatedly attempts to authenticate using various passwords (either manually or with an automated tool), and no successful authentication is observed.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Attack: Failed Brute Force Auth

commonEvent.name: AIE: Attack: Failed Brute Force Auth

name: Compromise: Distributed Brute Force
description:
A successful brute force authentication -- multiple failed authentication attempts from different external hosts to the same host using the same origin login, followed by an authentication success.

UTD
CTD
details:
Action: This rule fires when the attacker was able to compromise at least one account. In this case, it is vital to quickly contain the compromise by disconnecting infected hosts, disabling the compromised account, and
blocking the attacker's access -- organizations should have an incident response plan for a compromise. Also, after stopping the active attack, forensics will need to be conducted to insure that an implant isn't hidden
in the network, information wasn't stolen, or other accounts were compromised.

Configuration: In Windows, activate Audit Account Management for successes in the Group/Local Security Policy. 

Use Case: An attacker knows a login ID to a specific host and repeatedly attempts to authenticate using various passwords from different origin hosts in an attempt to mask the password guessing activity, and eventually successfully
authenticates.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: Distributed Brute Force

commonEvent.name: AIE: Compromise: Distributed Brute Force

name: C2: Concurrent VPN from Multiple Locations
description:
Multiple VPN authentication successes from the same origin login are observed from different regions within a given time period (default 3 hours).

UTD
details:
Use Case: An attacker is using a compromised account to authenticate at the same time as the actual user is authenticating with the same account from different regions.

Assumptions: GeoLocation is enabled.

alarmRule.name: AIE: C2: Concurrent VPN from Multiple Locations

commonEvent.name: AIE: C2: Concurrent VPN from Multiple Locations

values.displayValue: MIA: ID 0406 MUVPN User Logged In

name: Account Anomaly: Concurrent VPN from Multiple Countries
description:
Multiple VPN authentication successes from the same origin login are observed from different countries within a given time period (default 24 hours).

UTD
details:
Use Case: An attacker is using a compromised account to authenticate at the same time as the actual user is authenticating with the same account from different countries.

Assumptions: GeoLocation is enabled.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Account Anomaly: Concurrent VPN Mult Country

commonEvent.name: AIE: Account Anomaly: Concurrent VPN Mult Country

values.displayValue: MIA: ID 0406 MUVPN User Logged In

name: C2: Blacklist Location Auth
description:
Authentication success from a blacklisted location.

UTD
details:
Use Case: An attacker is using a compromised account to authenticate from a location deemed unauthorized.

Assumptions:  GeoLocation is enabled.

Configuration: Create an Include Filter where Location=list of unauthorized locations.

alarmRule.name: AIE: C2: Blacklist Location Auth

commonEvent.name: AIE: C2: Blacklist Location Auth

name: Compromise: Auth After Numerous Failed Auths
description:
Multiple external unique login attempts are seen on the same impacted host within a short period of time, followed by a successful authentication.

UTD
details: Use Case: A malicious individual has a list of common default accounts (default vendor accounts, common account names such as "user" "admin" "test" etc) and is attempting to authenticate with one of these accounts on a single machine, followed by a successful authentication on the same machine.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: Auth After Numerous Failed Auths

commonEvent.name: AIE: Compromise: Auth After Numerous Failed Auths

name: Attack: Failed Account Probe
description: Multiple external unique login attempts are made unsuccessfully on the same host within a short period of time.
details: Use Case: A malicious individual has a list of common default accounts (default vendor accounts, common account names such as "user" "admin" "test" etc) and is attempting to authenticate with one of these accounts on a single machine, with no successful authentication observed.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Attack: Failed Account Probe

commonEvent.name: AIE: Attack: Failed Account Probe

name: Recon: Failed Distributed Account Probe
description:
The same external account unsuccessfully attempts to authenticate to multiple hosts within a short period of time.


CTD
details:
Action: Responses to 'failure' alarms should include hardening the potential victim host and account and blocking the attacker. It is also useful to determine if the attack is a determined effort to compromise the network
or just a passing probe. Perform follow-up investigations for additional logs generated by the attacker and victim. Remember that a failure alarm may mean that the attacker was still successful in other attempts.

Use Case : A malicious individual finds a "sticky note" with a user name and password.  The attacker then attempts to use these credentials on several different hosts, with no successful authentication observed.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Recon: Failed Distributed Account Probe

commonEvent.name: AIE: Recon: Failed Distributed Account Probe

name: Lateral: Auth After Dispersed Failed Auths
description:
Within a short period of time, a single account unsuccessfully attempts to authenticate to multiple hosts from an external source.

UTD
details: Use Case: A malicious individual finds a "sticky note" with a user name and password.  The attacker then attempts to use these credentials on several different hosts, followed by a successful authentication.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Lateral: Auth After Dispersed Failed Auths

commonEvent.name: AIE: Lateral: Auth After Dispersed Failed Auths

name: Recon: Failed Distributed Brute Force
description:
Multiple failed authentication attempts from different external origin hosts to the same impacted host using the same origin login, without seeing an authentication success.

UTD
details: Use Case: An attacker knows a login id to a specific host and repeatedly attempts to authenticate using various passwords from different origin hosts in an attempt to mask the password guessing activity, and no successful authentication is observed.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Recon: Failed Distributed Brute Force

commonEvent.name: AIE: Recon: Failed Distributed Brute Force

name: CSC: Port Scan then Attack
description: Port scan on multiple unique impacted ports is followed by an attack/malware/compromise/critical/DoS event within an hour on one of the impacted hosts. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 9.6, CSC 12.4
details: Use Case:  An attacker wants to prevent the timely release of a signature file/software release, so the attacker successfully launches a DDoS attack resulting in an application/host crashing, preventing the release from happening on time.    Optional Configuration: Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Port Scan then Attack

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Port Scan then Attack

name: CSC: Possible DDoS Detected
description: Externally originating denial of service log messages with different Origin Hosts and same impacted host. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 9.6, CSC 12.4
details: Use Case: An attacker wants to prevent the timely release of a signature file/software release, so the attacker successfully launches a DDoS attack resulting in an application/host crashing, preventing the release from happening on time.    Configuration: The number of Unique Values in rule block 1 should be set to a value just above your organization's average number of unique web visitors per minute.  In addition, creating a new Primary Criteria filter where the Impacted Host is a list of publicly facing web servers will limit the rule to only evaluate traffic appropriate for the organization.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Possible DDoS Detected

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Possible DDoS Detected

name: CSC: Multiple Unique Attacks Observed
description: Multiple unique external attack events against the same host. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 8.1, CSC 12.4
details:
Use Case: An attacker is using an automated tool to launch a variety of attacks against a host.    
Optional Configuration: Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Multiple Unique Attacks Observed

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Multiple Unique Attacks Observed

name: SANS: General DoS
description:
An observed external denial of service log followed by a critical, error, or startup/shutdown on the same impacted host.

Modules:
Sans Top 20
APT
details:
Use Case: An attacker wants to prevent the timely release of a signature file/software release, so the attacker successfully launches a DoS attack resulting in an application/host crashing, preventing the release from happening on time.

Optional Configuration: Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

alarmRule.name: AIE: SANS: General DoS

commonEvent.name: AIE: SANS: General DoS

name: CSC: Data Exfiltration Observed
description: External attack or compromise followed by data leaving the same system. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 13.6
details: Use Case: An attacker is looking for sensitive financial information.  The attacker successfully compromises a host and is able to copy the information to a different external server.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Data Exfiltration Observed

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Data Exfiltration Observed

name: Lateral: External Attack then Account Creation
description:
Attack or compromise event from an external source followed by an account creation on the same host.

CTD
details:
Action: The cost and recovery time of a compromise grows exponentially with each stage of the attack cycle, so it is imperative to stop the attack as early as possible. These rules indicate that the attacker has moved past
the initial stages and is consolidating their beachhead. After the attack is stopped, it is very important to do a full sweep of the network for other signs of continued infection.

Use Case: A savvy hacker successfully attacked a machine to gain access. Once in the exploited machine the hacker now created an account to use for future use and exploitation.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Lateral: External Attack then Account Creation

commonEvent.name: AIE: Lateral: External Attack then Acct Creation

name: CSC: Attack then External Connection
description: An observed external attack or compromise followed by data leaving the system and going to the attacker. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 12.3
details: Use Case: An attacker is looking for sensitive financial information.  The attacker successfully compromises a host and is able to copy the information to the attacker's host.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Attack then External Connection

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Attack then External Connection

name: Compromise: Log Cleared
description:
A compromise event from an external source followed by the audit log being cleared on the same compromised host.

ETD
CTD
details:
Action: Clearing the audit log can be a way for an attacker or malware to hide its activity. Run investigations for the impacted host and user that performed the activity. Check what process cleared the audit log and make sure it's legitimate.

Use Case: An attacker compromises a host and clears the the audit log to cover their tracks.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: Log Cleared

commonEvent.name: AIE: Compromise: Log Cleared

values.displayValue: ID 010432013: User Has Removed or Cleared Log Data
ID 010432013: User Has Removed or Cleared Log Data

name: Attack: Recon Followed by Attack
description:
External reconnaissance event followed by an attack on the same host.

ETD
details:
Use Case : An attacker performed a port scan and realized that a particular host is using AltaVista Firewall97 and is now attacking this machine with the Amanda trojan via TCP port 28.

Optional Configuration: Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 2 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Attack: Recon Followed by Attack

commonEvent.name: AIE: Attack: Recon Followed by Attack

name: Attack: Critical Event After Attack
description:
An external attack or compromise followed by a critical event on the same host.

ETD
CTD
details:
Action: This alarm can identify when an error message is generated as the result of a successful attack. This can be unexpected process termination or a hardware failure. Investigate the impacted host to determine if the critical error message and attack are related. 

Use Case : An attacker has successfully launched an attack, allowing them to install malicious code that rapidly eats up resources causing the target machine's applications to crash.

Optional Configuration: Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 2 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Attack: Critical Event After Attack

commonEvent.name: AIE: Attack: Critical Event After Attack

name: Compromise: Recon then Process Starting
description:
Reconnaissance event against a host followed by a non-whitelisted process starting up on the same host, indicating a possible compromise.

ETD
details:
Use Case: An attacker scans a machine for a vulnerability.  The vulnerability is expoited, and a new malicious process is started up on the target machine.

Configuration: (1) Create an Exclude Filter in Rule Block 2 where Process=list of whitelisted processes.
	       (2) Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: Recon then Process Starting

commonEvent.name: AIE: Compromise: Recon then Process Starting

name: Compromise: Recon then Account Creation
description:
Reconnaissance from an external source followed by account creation on the same host.

UTD
details: Use Case : An attacker studies a host, launches an attack that has a non-observable signature, compromises the system and creates an account.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: Recon then Account Creation

commonEvent.name: AIE: Compromise: Recon then Account Creation

name: Compromise: Attack then New Process Starting
description:
An attack or compromise event followed by a non-whitelisted process starting up on the same host, indicating a possible compromise.

ETD
CTD
details:
Action: Often a successful attack involves new processes starting on a host. Investigate the impacted host and process to determine if the process is legitimate - for example infrequently scheduled tasks can be misidentified as a new process.

Use Case:  Attacker compromises system and launches a custom application to control the system.

Configuration: (1) Create an Exclude Filter in Rule Block 2 where Process = list of whitelisted processes.
	       (2) Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: Attack then New Process Starting

commonEvent.name: AIE: Compromise: Attack then New Process Starting

name: Compromise: Data Destruction
description:
Attack event followed by a FIM delete/modify event on the same host.

ETD
details:
Use Case: An attacker deletes a file that was being monitored.

Assumptions:  Critical files must be monitored by LogRhythm File Integrity Monitor.

Configuration:  (1) Critical files must be included in the LogRhythm File Integrity Monitor (FIM) Policy assigned to the LogRhythm System Monitor Agent.
	       (2) Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: Data Destruction

commonEvent.name: AIE: Compromise: Data Destruction

name: Compromise: Auth After Security Event
description: An observed attack, compromise, or other security event followed by successful access or authentication from the attacking host.
details: Use Case: An IDS has detected some sort of hacking activity from an external host.  Later, the same external host is seen successfully authenticating with an internal host, indicating a successful network penetration.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: Auth After Security Event

commonEvent.name: AIE: Compromise: Auth After Security Event

name: Recon: Port Sweep
description: Inbound TCP/UDP traffic on the same port to multiple internal hosts.
details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP and Origin Application if its known, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN, block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Impacted IP Host, Application and reputation are known, block the Impacted IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall if unknown or add to Watch List for further assessment.

Configuration: (1) Depending on how netflow is configured, standard web browsing traffic can be seen with a source IP of the egress route.  This activity will cause the rule to fire.  Create an Exclude Filter List "External IP Addresses" where IP (Source) = egress IP to filter out this activity. (2) Create an Exclude Filter List "Vulnerablility Scanners" for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

Use Case: An external attacker performing reconnaissance is aware of a vulnerability for a service for exploitation and is trying to identify if this service is running on any hosts within the network.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Recon: Port Sweep

commonEvent.name: AIE: Recon: Port Sweep

name: Recon: Port Sweep: Common Port
description:
Inbound TCP/UDP traffic on the same common port to multiple internal hosts.

NTD
details:
Use Case: An attacker is using a botnet to look for a specific vulnerable service in an attempt to circumvent standard IDS port scan alarming.

Optional Configuration: (1) Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.
		     (2) Include an IP Address (Impacted) exclude filter where IP Address (Impacted) is the external/public facing IPs of any firewall.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Recon: Port Sweep: Common Port

commonEvent.name: AIE: Recon: Port Sweep: Common Port

name: Lateral: Privilege Escalation after Attack
description:
Compromised host event followed by a new account created or account modified on the same host.

CTD
details:
Action: The cost and recovery time of a compromise grows exponentially with each stage of the attack cycle, so it is imperative to stop the attack as early as possible. These rules indicate that the attacker has moved past
the initial stages and is consolidating their beachhead. After the attack is stopped, it is very important to do a full sweep of the network for other signs of continued infection.

Use Case: An IDS has detected some sort of hacking activity from an external host. Later, the same external host is
seen successfully authenticating with an internal host, indicating a successful network penetration.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Lateral: Privilege Escalation after Attack

commonEvent.name: AIE: Lateral: Privilege Escalation after Attack

name: Recon: Port Scan: Slow
description:
External host slowly sending traffic to over 20 ports on an internal host, indicating a possible advanced port scan.

NTD
details:
Use Case: An attacker is running a slow port scan (trying to hide their reconnasance efforts) to determine which services are running on a target machine.

Optional Configuration: Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Recon: Port Scan: Slow

commonEvent.name: AIE: Recon: Port Scan: Slow

name: Recon: Ping Sweep
description:
Inbound ICMP packets from one source to multiple internal hosts.

NTD
details:
Use Case:  A potential attacker searches for computers on the Internet using ICMP Ping.

Optional Configuration: (1) Depending on the size of the environment the unqiue values count may need to be increased.
		     (2) Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Recon: Ping Sweep

commonEvent.name: AIE: Recon: Ping Sweep

name: Recon: Port Scan
description: External host sending traffic to over 40 ports on an internal host, indicating a possible port scan.
details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP and Origin Application if its known, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN, block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Impacted IP Host, Application and reputation are known, block the Impacted IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall if unknown or add to Watch List for further assessment.

Optional Configuration: Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

Use Case: An external attacker is running a port scan to determine which services are running on a target machine.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Recon: Port Scan

commonEvent.name: AIE: Recon: Port Scan

name: Account Anomaly: Mass File Deletion by Admin
description:
An observed administrator login followed by multiple file deletions, indicating the administrator may be destroying large amounts of data.

ETD
details:
Use Case : A disgruntled administrator wants to disrupt company workflow by deleting commonly used files on a shared drive.

Configuration:  A Primary Criteria Filter should be added to RB1 where Origin Login = list of privileged user ids.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Account Anomaly: Mass File Deletion by Admin

commonEvent.name: AIE: Account Anomaly: Mass File Deletion by Admin

name: CSC: Password Modified on Multiple Accounts
description: A user has modified the password on 3 or more accounts in one hour. This can indicate a compromised account or malicious insider activity. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 16.14, CSC 5.1
details:
Use Case:  Administrator changes passwords on multiple accounts to either use as future backdoors or to prevent users from logging in.    
Configuration:  A Primary Criteria Filter should be added to RB1 where Origin Login = list of privileged user ids.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Password Modified on Multiple Accounts

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Password Modified on Multiple Accounts

name: CSC: Audit Disabled by Admin
description: Login by an administrator followed by disabling of an audit process.  CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 6.2, CSC 5.1
details:
Use Case: A disgruntled administrator plans on malicious activity and disables auditing beforehand to ensure the activity isn't logged.    
Configuration:  A include filter where Origin Login = list of privileged user ids must be entered into RB1.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Audit Disabled by Admin

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Audit Disabled by Admin

values.displayValue: MID CPI2284 : Qaudctl System Value Changed
MID CPI2283 : Qaudctl System Value Changed
RAS-2002 INFO : User Disabled Audit Message Log

name: CSC: Temporary Account Used
description: An account is created, logged into, and then deleted within 1 day.  CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 5.4
details: Use Case: Administrator creates, uses and deletes an account to possibly try and avoid discovery of an activity performed on the newly created account.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Temporary Account Used

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Temporary Account Used

name: Account Anomaly: Concurrent VPN from Multiple Cities
description:
Multiple VPN authentication successes from the same origin login are observed from different cities within a given time period (default 30 minutes).

UTD
details:
Use Case: An attacker is using a compromised account to authenticate at the same time as the actual user is authenticating with the same account from different cities.

Assumptions: GeoLocation is set to resolve to the city level

alarmRule.name: AIE: Account Anomaly: Concurrent VPN Multiple City

commonEvent.name: AIE: Account Anomaly: Concurrent VPN Multiple City

values.displayValue: MIA: ID 0406 MUVPN User Logged In

name: CSC: Local Account Created and Used
description: An account is created on a host and then used shortly thereafter on the same host.  CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 5.4
details: Use Case:  A disgruntled administrator creates a dummy account to use temporarily while performing malicious activities in an attempt to mask who is performing the activity.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Local Account Created and Used

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Local Account Created and Used

description: The same internal account is used to attempt to authenticate to multiple hosts within a short period of time, followed by a successful authentication.
details: Use Case: A malicious individual finds a "sticky note" with a user name and password.  The attacker then attempts to use these credentials on several different hosts, followed by a successful authentication.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: Lateral Movement With Account Sweep

commonEvent.name: AIE: Compromise: Lateral Movement With Acct Sweep

name: Compromise: Internal Brute Force Auth
description:
Multiple failed authentication attempts from the same internal origin host to the same impacted host, followed by an authentication success from the same origin host to the same impacted host.

UTD
details: Use Case : An attacker knows a login id to a specific host and repeatedly attempts to authenticate using various passwords (either manually or with an automated tool), and eventually successfully authenticates.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: Internal Brute Force Auth

commonEvent.name: AIE: Compromise: Internal Brute Force Auth

Multiple, unique unsuccessful login attempts from an internal host are made on the same impacted host within a short period of time.

UTD
details:
Use Case: A malicious individual has a list of common default accounts (default vendor accounts, common account names such as "user" "admin" "test" etc) and is attempting to authenticate with one of these accounts on a single machine, with no successful authentication observed.

Optional Configuration : Depending on the environment the amount of unique values may need to be increased for Rule Block 1. An authentication failure log is created by each domain controller in your environment.

name: Lateral: Numerous and Dispersed Internal Failed Auths
description:
The same internal account unsuccessfully attempts to authenticate to multiple hosts within a short period of time.

UTD
details: Use Case: A malicious individual finds a "sticky note" with a user name and password.  The attacker then attempts to use these credentials on several different hosts, with no successful authentication observed.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Lateral: Numerous and Dispersed Internal Fail

commonEvent.name: AIE: Lateral: Dispersed Internal Failed Auths

description: Successful brute force authentication from an internal source -- ie several internal hosts using the same account to first fail multiple times to authenticate before successfully logging in.s:
details: Use Case: Several compromised hosts are being used to perform a distributed brute force attack against a single host.

Multiple failed authentication attempts from the same internal origin host to the same impacted host, without seeing an authentication success.

details: Use Case : An attacker knows a login id to a specific host and repeatedly attempts to authenticate using various passwords (either manually or with an automated tool), and no successful authentication is observed.

details: Use Case: An attacker knows a login id to a specific host and repeatedly attempts to authenticate using various passwords from different origin hosts in an attempt to mask the password guessing activity, and no successful authentication is observed.

Multiple internal unique login attempts are seen on the same impacted host within a short period of time, followed by a successful authentication.

Use Case: A malicious individual has a list of common default accounts (default vendor accounts, common account names such as "user" "admin" "test" etc) and is attempting to authenticate with one of these accounts on a single machine, followed by a successful authentication on the same machine.

Optional Configuration : Depending on the environment the amount of unique values may need to be increased for Rule Block 1. An authentication failure log is created by each domain controller in your environment.

name: Disruption: Denial of Service

details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP and Origin Application if its known, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN, block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Impacted IP Host, Application and reputation are known, block the Impacted IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall if unknown or add to Watch List for further assessment.

Use Case: An attacker wants to prevent the timely release of a signature file/software release, so the attacker successfully launches a DoS attack resulting in an application/host crashing, preventing the release from happening on time. A Denial of Service event identified impacting or originating from an internal host.

name: Compromise: Internal Port Scan then Attack
description:
Port scan on multiple, unique ports followed by an attack/malware/compromise/critical/DoS event within a given time period on one of the impacted hosts (default 1 hour).

ETD
details:
Use Case: An attacker scanned a host to see which services were running on it.  The attacker found a vulnerable service and has launched an attack.

Optional Configuration: Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: Internal Port Scan then Attack

commonEvent.name: AIE: Compromise: Internal Port Scan then Attack

name: Compromise: Multiple Unique Attack Events
description: Multiple, unique attack events against the same host.
details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP and Origin Application if its known, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN, block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Impacted IP Host, Application and reputation are known, block the Impacted IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall if unknown or add to Watch List for further assessment.

Optional Configuration: Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

Use Case: An attacker is using an automated tool to launch a variety of attacks against a host.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: Multiple Unique Attack Events

name: Lateral: Internal Attack then Account Creation
description:
Attack or compromise event from an internal host followed by an account creation on the victim host.

CTD
details:
Action: Because the attack has already progressed to an advanced stage, it is imperative to stem the damage and stop the attack as early as possible. These rules indicate that the attacker has moved past the initial
stages, is spreading throughout the network, and likely has already begun to pillage. After the attack is stopped, use the logs from the alarm to help with a full sweep of the network for other signs of continued
infection.

Use Case: A system is successfully attacked, and the attacker then creates a new account on the system in order to maintain access.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Lateral: Internal Attack then Account Creation

commonEvent.name: AIE: Lateral: Internal Attack then Acct Creation

name: C2: Spamming Bot
description: Non-mail server sending mail out to multiple, unique, external SMTP servers within a very short period of time.
details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP if its a known Email Server or if the emailing service is known, quarantine unknown emailing systems to a Remediation VLAN and block the Origin IP outbound on the Firewall.

Configuration:  (1) Create an Exclude Filter where Origin Host = mail servers.          (2) Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

Use Case: A compromised host that has become a botnet zombie is being used to send spam messages.

alarmRule.name: AIE: C2: Spamming Bot

commonEvent.name: AIE: C2: Spamming Bot

name: Attack: Internal Recon then Attack
description:
Reconnaissance event against a host followed by an attack.

ETD
details:
Use Case:  An internal malicious employee scans an accounting machine for a vulnerability, then attempts to exploit a vulnerability that was found.

Optional Configuration: Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 and/or Rule Block 2 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Attack: Internal Recon then Attack

commonEvent.name: AIE: Attack: Internal Recon then Attack

Attack or compromise event from an internal host followed by a FIM delete/modify event on the victim host.

ETD

name: Recon: Internal Port Sweep
description:
Internal host sweeping the internal network with traffic on the same port.

NTD
details:
Use Case : An external attacker performing reconnaissance is aware of a vulnerability for a particular service to exploit and is trying to identify if this service is running on any hosts within the network.

Configuration : (1) Depending on how netflow is configured, standard web browsing traffic can be seen all with a source IP of the egress route.  This activity will cause the rule to fire.  Create an Exclude Filter                              where IP (Source) = egress IP to filter out this activity.
	       (2) Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

		     (2) Create an Exclude Filter for commonly used ports used by white listed applications and services.

name: Compromise: Attack then Critical Event
description: Attack event against a host followed by an error on the same host.
details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP if its a known host, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN and block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Impacted IP was compromised and remediate as necessary otherwise add Impacted IP to a Watch List to determine if Attack was successful.

name: Compromise: Malware: Outbreak
description:
Multiple observed malware detections or malware failed detections within a given period of time on different impacted hosts - grouped by common event.

ETD
CTD
details:
Action:This alarm may signify that an individual malware event collected by the SIEM is part of a larger infection across the network. Investigate the impacted hosts and check your antimalware system to determine if the malware was successfully quarantined or cleaned.

Use Case : A worm is successfully spreading throughout the network.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: Malware: Outbreak

commonEvent.name: AIE: Compromise: Malware: Outbreak

name: C2: Excessive Unique Outbound Connections
description: Excessive network connections (default of 100) on any port other than 80 or 443.
details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP if its a known host, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN and block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Impacted IP is known and reputable along with if Impacted Port is a known application. Determine if Origin IP was compromised and remediate as necessary otherwise add Impacted IP to a Watch List to determine if Attack was successful.

Configuration:  (1) Mail Servers generally have a large number of unique outbound connections.  Create an exclude filter using List "Mail Servers" where Origin Host = mail servers to ensure normal SMTP activity doesn't trigger this rule. 

Optional Configuration: (1) Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners. (2) Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the host name of any Proxies.

Use Case: An internal user is using BitTorrent to download a pirated movie or an internal user is using Skype.  Excessive outbound network connections (default of 100) on any port other than 53, 80 or 443.

alarmRule.name: AIE: C2: Excessive Unique Outbound Connections

commonEvent.name: AIE: C2: Excessive Unique Outbound Connections

name: PCI-DSS: Account Disabled/Locked AIE Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates events for disabled/locked accounts in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 8.1.3a, 8.1.4, 8.1.6.a, 8.1.6.b, 8.1.7
details:
8.1.3.a Select a sample of users terminated in the past six months, and review current user access listsfor both local and remote accessto verify that their IDs have been deactivated or removed from the access lists.
8.1.4 Observe user accounts to verify that any inactive accounts over 90 days old are either removed or disabled.
8.1.6.a For a sample of system components, inspect system configuration settings to verify that authentication parameters are set to require that user accounts be locked out after not more than six invalid logon attempts.
8.1.6.b Additional testing procedure for service provider assessments only: Review internal processes and customer/user documentation, and observe implemented processes to verify that non-consumer customer user accounts are temporarily locked-out after not more than six invalid access attempts.
8.1.7 For a sample of system components, inspect system configuration settings to verify that password parameters are set to require that once a user account is locked out, it remains locked for a minimum of 30 minutes or until a system administrator resets the account.

alarmRule.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Account Disabled/Locked AIE Rule

commonEvent.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Account Disabled/Locked

name: PCI-DSS: Antivirus Information AIE Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates events for antivirus information in direct support of PCI-DSS Controls: 5.2.d and in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 5.1, 5.2.b-d
details:
5.1 For a sample of system components including all operating system types commonly affected by malicious software, verify that anti-virus software is deployed if applicable anti-virus technology exists.
5.2.b Examine anti-virus configurations, including the master installation of the software to verify anti-virus mechanisms are:
- Configured to perform automatic updates, and
- Configured to perform periodic scans.
5.2.c Examine a sample of system components, including all operating system types commonly affected by malicious software, to verify that:
- The anti-virus software and definitions are current.
- Periodic scans are performed.
5.2.d Examine anti-virus configurations, including the master installation of the software and a sample of system components, to verify that:
- Anti-virus software log generation is enabled, and
- Logs are retained in accordance with PCI DSS Requirement 10.7.

name: PCI-DSS: FIM Add Activity AIE Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates events for all file integrity monitoring add activity in direct support of PCI-DSS Controls: 11.5.a-b and in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 3.6.7a, 10.2.7
details:
3.6.7.a Verify that key-management procedures specify processes to prevent unauthorized substitution of keys.
10.2.7 Verify creation and deletion of system level objects are logged.
11.5.a Verify the use of a change-detection mechanism within the cardholder data environment by observing system settings and monitored files, as well as reviewing results from monitoring activities.
Examples of files that should be monitored:
- System executables
- Application executables
- Configuration and parameter files
- Centrally stored, historical or archived, log and audit files
- Additional critical files determined by entity (for example, through risk assessment or other means).
11.5.b Verify the mechanism is configured to alert personnel to unauthorized modification (including changes, additions, and deletions) of critical files, and to perform critical file comparisons at least weekly.

name: PCI-DSS: Database Authentication AIE Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates events for database authentication successes & failures from unauthorized accounts in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 8.7.a,c,d and in direct support of PCI-DSS Controls: 10.2.1, 10.2.4
details:
8.7.a Review database and application configuration settings and verify that all users are authenticated prior to access.
8.7.c Examine database access control settings and database application configuration settings to verify that user direct access to or queries of databases are restricted to database administrators.
8.7.d Examine database access control settings, database application configuration settings, and the related application IDs to verify that application IDs can only be used by the applications (and not by individual users or other processes).
10.2.1 Verify all individual access to cardholder data is logged.
10.2.4 Verify invalid logical access attempts are logged.

alarmRule.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Database Authentication AIE Rule

commonEvent.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Database Authentication

name: PCI-DSS: Invalid Account Usage AIE Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates events for authentication successes and failures from unauthorized accounts in direct support of PCI-DSS Controls: 2.1.a-b, 10.2.1, 10.2.4 & in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 8.1.3.a, 8.1.4, 8.5.c
details:
2.1.a Choose a sample of system components, and attempt to log on (with system administrator help) to the devices and applications using default vendor-supplied accounts and passwords, to verify that ALL default passwords (including those on operating systems, software that provides security services, application and system accounts, POS terminals, and Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) community strings) have been changed. (Use vendor manuals and sources on the Internet to find vendor-supplied accounts/passwords.)
2.1.b For the sample of system components, verify that all unnecessary default accounts (including accounts used by operating systems, security software, applications, systems, POS terminals, SNMP, etc.) are removed or disabled.
8.1.3.a Select a sample of users terminated in the past six months, and review current user access listsfor both local and remote accessto verify that their IDs have been deactivated or removed from the access lists.
8.1.4 Observe user accounts to verify that any inactive accounts over 90 days old are either removed or disabled.
8.5.c Interview system administrators to verify that group and shared IDs and/or passwords or other authentication methods are not distributed, even if requested.
10.2.1 Verify all individual access to cardholder data is logged.
10.2.4 Verify invalid logical access attempts are logged.

name: PCI-DSS: Physical Access Usage AIE Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates events of physical security authentication success and failures in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 8.1.3.b, 9.1, 9.1.1.a, 9.1.2 & 9.3.c
details:
8.1.3.b Verify all physical authentication methodssuch as, smart cards, tokens, etc.have been returned or deactivated.
9.1 Verify the existence of physical security controls for each computer room, data center, and other physical areas with systems in the cardholder data environment.
- Verify that access is controlled with badge readers or other devices including authorized badges and lock and key.
- Observe a system administrators attempt to log into consoles for randomly selected systems in the cardholder environment and verify that they are locked to prevent unauthorized use.
9.1.1.a Verify that video cameras and/or access control mechanisms are in place to monitor the entry/exit points to sensitive areas.
9.1.2 Interview responsible personnel and observe locations of publicly accessible network jacks to verify that physical and/or logical controls are in place to restrict access to publicly accessible network jacks.
9.3.c Select a sample of recently terminated employees and review access control lists to verify the personnel do not have physical access to sensitive areas.

alarmRule.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Physical Access Usage AIE Rule

commonEvent.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Physical Access Usage

name: PCI-DSS: Vendor Auth Activity AIE Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates events for vendor account activity in direct support of PCI-DSS Controls: 10.2.1, 10.2.4 and in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 8.1.5.a, 8.1.5.b, 8.1.6.b, 12.3.9
details:
8.1.5.a Interview personnel and observe processes for managing accounts used by vendors to access, support, or maintain system components to verify that accounts used by vendors for remote access are:
- Disabled when not in use
- Enabled only when needed by the vendor, and disabled when not in use.
8.1.5.b Interview personnel and observe processes to verify that vendor remote access accounts are monitored while being used.
8.1.6.b Additional testing procedure for service provider assessments only: Review internal processes and customer/user documentation, and observe implemented processes to verify that non-consumer customer user accounts are temporarily locked-out after not more than six invalid access attempts.
10.2.1 Verify all individual access to cardholder data is logged.
10.2.4 Verify invalid logical access attempts are logged.
12.3.9 Verify that the usage policies require activation of remote-access technologies used by vendors and business partners only when needed by vendors and business partners, with immediate deactivation after use.

name: PCI-DSS: Host Firewall Information AIE Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates events for host firewall information in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 1.4.a
details:
1.4.a Examine policies and configuration standards to verify:
- Personal firewall software is required for all mobile and/or employee-owned devices that connect to the Internet when outside the network (for example, laptops used by employees), and which are also used to access the network.
- Specific configuration settings are defined for personal firewall software.
- Personal firewall software is configured to actively run.
- Personal firewall software is configured to not be alterable by users of mobile and/or employee-owned devices.

name: PCI-DSS: Denied CDE => Internet Comm AIE Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates events for denied communication from the cardholder data environment to the external internet in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 1.2.1.a-c, 1.3.3, 1.3.5, & 2.2.2.a-b
details:
1.2.1.a Examine firewall and router configuration standards to verify that they identify inbound and outbound traffic necessary for the cardholder data environment.
1.2.1.b Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that inbound and outbound traffic is limited to that which is necessary for the cardholder data environment.
1.2.1.c Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that all other inbound and outbound traffic is specifically denied, for example by using an explicit deny all or an implicit deny after allow statement.
1.3.3 Examine firewall and router configurations to verify direct connections inbound or outbound are not allowed for traffic between the Internet and the cardholder data environment.
1.3.5 Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that outbound traffic from the cardholder data environment to the Internet is explicitly authorized.
2.2.2.a Select a sample of system components and inspect enabled system services, daemons, and protocols to verify that only necessary services or protocols are enabled.
2.2.2.b Identify any enabled insecure services, daemons, or protocols and interview personnel to verify they are justified per documented configuration standards.

description: This AIE Rule creates events for denied communication from the internal environment to the external internet in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 2.2.2.a-b, 2.3.b, & 4.1.c,f
details:
2.2.2.a Select a sample of system components and inspect enabled system services, daemons, and protocols to verify that only necessary services or protocols are enabled.

name: PCI-DSS: Denied Test => Internal Comm AIE Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates events for denied communication from the test environment to other internal environments in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 1.2.1.a-c, 2.2.2.a-b, 6.4.1.a-b, 6.4.2
details:
1.2.1.a Examine firewall and router configuration standards to verify that they identify inbound and outbound traffic necessary for the cardholder data environment.
1.2.1.b Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that inbound and outbound traffic is limited to that which is necessary for the cardholder data environment.
1.2.1.c Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that all other inbound and outbound traffic is specifically denied, for example by using an explicit deny all or an implicit deny after allow statement.
2.2.2.a Select a sample of system components and inspect enabled system services, daemons, and protocols to verify that only necessary services or protocols are enabled.
2.2.2.b Identify any enabled insecure services, daemons, or protocols and interview personnel to verify they are justified per documented configuration standards.
6.4.1.a Examine network documentation and network device configurations to verify that the development/test environments are separate from the production environment(s).
6.4.1.b Examine access controls settings to verify that access controls are in place to enforce separation between the development/test environments and the production environment(s).
6.4.2 Observe processes and interview personnel assigned to development/test environments and personnel assigned to production environments to verify that separation of duties is in place between development/test environments and the production environment.

description: This AIE Rule creates events for un-allowed communication from the cardholder data environment to the external internet in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 1.2.1.a-c, 1.3.3, 1.3.5, & 2.2.2.a-b
details:
1.2.1.a Examine firewall and router configuration standards to verify that they identify inbound and outbound traffic necessary for the cardholder data environment.
1.2.1.b Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that inbound and outbound traffic is limited to that which is necessary for the cardholder data environment.
1.2.1.c Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that all other inbound and outbound traffic is specifically denied, for example by using an explicit deny all or an implicit deny after allow statement.
1.3.3 Examine firewall and router configurations to verify direct connections inbound or outbound are not allowed for traffic between the Internet and the cardholder data environment.
1.3.5 Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that outbound traffic from the cardholder data environment to the Internet is explicitly authorized.
2.2.2.a Select a sample of system components and inspect enabled system services, daemons, and protocols to verify that only necessary services or protocols are enabled.
2.2.2.b Identify any enabled insecure services, daemons, or protocols and interview personnel to verify they are justified per documented configuration standards.

details:
1.2.1.a Examine firewall and router configuration standards to verify that they identify inbound and outbound traffic necessary for the cardholder data environment.

1.2.1.c Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that all other inbound and outbound traffic is specifically denied, for example by using an explicit deny all or an implicit deny after allow statement.
1.3.3 Examine firewall and router configurations to verify direct connections inbound or outbound are not allowed for traffic between the Internet and the cardholder data environment.
1.3.4 Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that anti-spoofing measures are implemented, for example internal addresses cannot pass from the Internet into the DMZ.
2.2.2.a Select a sample of system components and inspect enabled system services, daemons, and protocols to verify that only necessary services or protocols are enabled.

name: PCI-DSS: Invalid Inet => Intrn Comm AIE Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates events for un-allowed communication from the external internet to all internal environments in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 1.2.1.a-c, 1.2.3.b, 1.3.1, 1.3.2, & 2.2.2.a-b
details:
1.2.1.a Examine firewall and router configuration standards to verify that they identify inbound and outbound traffic necessary for the cardholder data environment.
1.2.1.b Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that inbound and outbound traffic is limited to that which is necessary for the cardholder data environment.
1.2.1.c Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that all other inbound and outbound traffic is specifically denied, for example by using an explicit deny all or an implicit deny after allow statement.
1.2.3.b Verify that the firewalls deny or, if traffic is necessary for business purposes, permit only authorized traffic between the wireless environment and the cardholder data environment.
1.3.1 Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that a DMZ is implemented to limit inbound traffic to only system components that provide authorized publicly accessible services, protocols, and ports.
1.3.2 Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that inbound Internet traffic is limited to IP addresses within the DMZ.
2.2.2.a Select a sample of system components and inspect enabled system services, daemons, and protocols to verify that only necessary services or protocols are enabled.
2.2.2.b Identify any enabled insecure services, daemons, or protocols and interview personnel to verify they are justified per documented configuration standards.

description: This AIE Rule creates events for un-allowed communication from the internal environment to the external internet in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 2.2.2.a-b, 2.3.b, & 4.1.c,f
details:
2.2.2.a Select a sample of system components and inspect enabled system services, daemons, and protocols to verify that only necessary services or protocols are enabled.
2.2.2.b Identify any enabled insecure services, daemons, or protocols and interview personnel to verify they are justified per documented configuration standards.

name: PCI-DSS: Invalid Test => Internal Comm AIE Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates events for un-allowed communication from the test environment to other internal environments in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 1.2.1.a-c, 2.2.2.a-b, 6.4.1.a-b, 6.4.2
details:
1.2.1.a Examine firewall and router configuration standards to verify that they identify inbound and outbound traffic necessary for the cardholder data environment.
1.2.1.b Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that inbound and outbound traffic is limited to that which is necessary for the cardholder data environment.
1.2.1.c Examine firewall and router configurations to verify that all other inbound and outbound traffic is specifically denied, for example by using an explicit deny all or an implicit deny after allow statement.
2.2.2.a Select a sample of system components and inspect enabled system services, daemons, and protocols to verify that only necessary services or protocols are enabled.
2.2.2.b Identify any enabled insecure services, daemons, or protocols and interview personnel to verify they are justified per documented configuration standards.
6.4.1.a Examine network documentation and network device configurations to verify that the development/test environments are separate from the production environment(s).
6.4.1.b Examine access controls settings to verify that access controls are in place to enforce separation between the development/test environments and the production environment(s).
6.4.2 Observe processes and interview personnel assigned to development/test environments and personnel assigned to production environments to verify that separation of duties is in place between development/test environments and the production environment.

details:
1.2.1.a Verify that inbound and outbound traffic is limited to that which is necessary for the cardholder data environment, and that the restrictions are documented.
1.2.1.b Verify that all other inbound and outbound traffic is specifically denied, for example by using an explicit deny all or an implicit deny after allow statement.
2.2.2.a For a sample of system components, inspect enabled system services, daemons, and protocols. Verify that only necessary services or protocols are enabled.
2.2.2.b Identify any enabled insecure services, daemons, or protocols. Verify they are justified and that security features are documented and implemented.
6.4.1 The development/test environments are separate from the production environment, with access control in place to enforce the separation.
6.4.2 There is a separation of duties between personnel assigned to the development/test environments and those assigned to the production environment.

name: Disruption: Files Deleted by Admin
description:
Privileged user login followed by multiple file deletions, indicating the administrator may be destroying large amounts of data.

UTD
details:
Use Case : A disgruntled administrator wants to disrupt company workflow by deleting commonly used files on a shared drive.

Configuration:  A Primary Criteria Filter should be added to RB1 where Origin Login = list of privileged user ids.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Disruption: Files Deleted by Admin

commonEvent.name: AIE: Disruption: Files Deleted by Admin

name: Lateral: Multiple Account Passwords Modified by Admin
description:
An observed login by a user in the privileged user list followed by the change of two or more other account passwords.

UTD
details:
Use Case:  Administrator changes passwords on multiple accounts to either use as future backdoors or to prevent users from logging in.

Configuration:  A Primary Criteria Filter should be added to RB1 where Origin Login = list of privileged user ids.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Lateral: Multiple Account Passwords Modified

commonEvent.name: AIE: Lateral: Multi Passwords Modified by Admin

name: CSC: Accounts Deleted by Admin
description: An observed login by a user in the privileged user list followed by the deletion of more than one account. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 16.3, CSC 3.6
details:
Use Case: A disgruntled administrator wants to disrupt company workflow by deleting multiple critical user accounts.    
Optional configuration: The unique vaule threshold may need to be increased in Rule Block 2 for larger environments where batch account lock-out/disabling occurs. (Default is 2 occurrences within 1 hour)

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Accounts Deleted by Admin

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Accounts Deleted by Admin

name: CSC: Accounts Disabled by Admin
description: An observed login by a user in the privileged user list followed by the disabling of more than one account. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 16.3, CSC 3.6
details:
Use Case: Administrator attempts to prevent users from logging in by disabling multiple accounts.    
Configuration: A Primary Criteria Filter should be added to RB1 where Origin Login = list of privileged user ids.    
Optional configuration: The unique value threshold may need to be increased in Rule Block 2 for larger environments where batch account lock-out/disabling occurs. (Default is 2 occurrences within 1 hour)

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Accounts Disabled by Admin

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Accounts Disabled by Admin

name: CSC: Users Added to Admin Group
description: Addition of 3 or more users to a group listed in the LogRhythm list "Privileged Groups". CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 5.4, CSC 3.6
details: Use Case: An attacker has compromised a domain controller and has created several new accounts to help maintain access, adding them to the Domain Admins group.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Users Added to Admin Group

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Users Added to Admin Group

name: CSC: Users Removed from Admin Group
description: Removal of 3 or more users from a group listed in the LogRhythm list "Privileged Groups" CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 5.4, CSC 3.6
details: Use Case: A rogue administrator wants to block access to the domain to all other administrators in order to perform malicious activity without anyone being able to respond.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Users Removed from Admin Group

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Users Removed from Admin Group

name: CSC: Windows RunAs Privilege Escalation
description: User not in the LogRhythm List "Privileged Users" chooses to Run a Windows program as an administrator using the "Run as administrator" option. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 5.8, CSC 3.6
details: Use Case: You've hardened all the security settings on your internal chat sever (e.g., Microsoft Lync) and someone is trying to install a MITM spyware to capture chats. The malicious user needs to run the spyware as administrator to access various registry settings needed to complete the attack.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Windows RunAs Privilege Escalation

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Windows RunAs Privilege Escalation

name: Account Anomaly: Failed Auth to Admin Exchange Accounts
description:
User repeatedly tries to access another user's Exchange account that is specified in the "Sensitive Users Emails" list.

UTD
details: Use Case: A sysadmin is accessing the CEO's mailbox and leveraging confidential information to negotiate for a salary increase.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Account Anomaly: Failed Auth Admin Exchange

commonEvent.name: AIE: Account Anomaly: Failed Auth Admin Exchange

details:

Smart response needs to be configured for when this rule fires to automatically add this user to the privileged user list

alarmRule.name: AIE: Lateral: Account Added to Admin Group

commonEvent.name: AIE: Lateral: Account Added to Admin Group

name: CSC: Linux sudo Privilege Escalation
description: User not in the LogRhythm list "Privileged Users" and not in the local 'sudoers' file tries to use sudo on a Linux host. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 5.8, CSC 3.6
details: Use Case: An attacker is testing their access by trying to run malicious code on a linux box without super user privileges. Required Configuration: "Privileged Users" list must be populated.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Linux sudo Privilege Escalation

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Linux sudo Privilege Escalation

name: Host Anomaly: New Process and Traffic Destination
description:
First, a process that normally doesn't run on the source host is started. Next, network traffic is generated from that process going to a host that the source doesn't normally communicate with.

ETD
details: Use Case : You've downloaded a fake anti virus scanner that, once executed, creates a reverse TCP shell to a command and control server that allows an attacker to take over your machine.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Host Anomaly: New Process and Traffic Dest

commonEvent.name: AIE: Host Anomaly: New Process and Traffic Dest

name: Host Anomaly: Unusual Auth then Unusual Process
description:
First tracks normal hosts accessed by a user and which processes are used. Afterwards, triggers when the user authenticates to a different host and starts a process that was not seen in the same learning period.

ETD
details: Use Case : An sys admin's credentials have been compromised and a user has used those credentials to log into your webserver to install the Incognito toolkit that now allows other attackers and trojans to exploit your webserver via the internet.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Host Anomaly: Unusual Auth then Unusual Proc

commonEvent.name: AIE: Host Anomaly: Unusual Auth then Unusual Proc

name: Account Anomaly: Abnormal Auth with Access
description:
First tracks which hosts an account typically authenticates to and which files they access. Afterwards, the event will trigger when a user authenticates to a different host and accesses an object they do not normally access.

UTD
details: Use Case : A malicious user has captured the exchange server admins credentials through a spear phishing attack. That user has now logged in and is starting to read the CEOs email.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Account Anomaly: Abnormal Auth with Access

commonEvent.name: AIE: Account Anomaly: Abnormal Auth with Access

name: Ops Config: Misconfiguration
description: First tracks which error, warning, and critical events normally occur on a host. Afterwards, triggers when a new type of event occurs.
details: Use Case : A professional services engineer has incorrectly configured the system monitor agent and now an object refence is not set to an instance of an object.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Ops Config: Misconfiguration

commonEvent.name: AIE: Ops Config: Misconfiguration

name: PCI-DSS: Antivirus Failure Alert Rule
description: This AIE Rule alerts on the occurrence of any critical failure or error to antivirus in direct support of PCI-DSS Controls: 5.2.d and in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 5.1, 5.2.b-c
details:
5.1 For a sample of system components including all operating system types commonly affected by malicious software, verify that anti-virus software is deployed if applicable anti-virus technology exists.
5.2.b Examine anti-virus configurations, including the master installation of the software to verify anti-virus mechanisms are:
- Configured to perform automatic updates, and
- Configured to perform periodic scans.
5.2.c Examine a sample of system components, including all operating system types commonly affected by malicious software, to verify that:
- The anti-virus software and definitions are current.
- Periodic scans are performed.
5.2.d Examine anti-virus configurations, including the master installation of the software and a sample of system components, to verify that:
- Anti-virus software log generation is enabled, and
- Logs are retained in accordance with PCI DSS Requirement 10.7.

alarmRule.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Antivirus Failure Alert Rule

commonEvent.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Antivirus Failure Alert Rule

values.displayValue: Unable To Download Virus Signature List

name: PCI-DSS: Attack Alert Rule
description: This AIE Rule alerts on the occurrence of any identified attack event in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 6.5.8, 6.6, 11.4.a-c, 12.10.5
details:
6.5.8 A direct object reference occurs when a developer exposes a reference to an internal implementation object, such as a file, directory, database record, or key, as a URL or form parameter. Attackers can manipulate those references to access other objects without authorization.
6.6 Public-facing web applications are primary targets for attackers, and poorly coded web applications provide an easy path for attackers to gain access to sensitive data and systems. The requirement for reviewing applications or installing web-application firewalls is intended to reduce the number of compromises on public-facing web applications due to poor coding or application management practices.
- Manual or automated vulnerability security assessment tools or methods review and/or test the application for vulnerabilities
- Web-application firewalls filter and block non-essential traffic at the application layer. Used in conjunction with a network-based firewall, a properly configured web-application firewall prevents application-layer attacks if applications are improperly coded or configured. This can be achieved through a combination of technology and process. Process-based solutions must have mechanisms that facilitate timely responses to alerts in order to meet the intent of this requirement, which is to prevent attacks. 
11.4.a-c
12.10.5 Verify through observation and review of processes that monitoring and responding to alerts from security monitoring systems are covered in the incident response plan.

alarmRule.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Attack Alert Rule

commonEvent.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Attack Alert Rule

name: PCI-DSS: Compromise Alert Rule
description: This AIE Rule alerts on the occurrence of any identified compromise event in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 11.4.a-c, 12.10.5
details:
11.4.a Examine system configurations and network diagrams to verify that techniques (such as intrusion-detection systems and/or intrusion-prevention systems) are in place to monitor all traffic:
- At the perimeter of the cardholder data environment
- At critical points in the cardholder data environment.
11.4.b Examine system configurations and interview responsible personnel to confirm intrusion-detection and/or intrusion-prevention techniques alert personnel of suspected compromises.
11.4.c Examine IDS/IPS configurations and vendor documentation to verify intrusion-detection and/or intrusion-prevention techniques are configured, maintained, and updated per vendor instructions to ensure optimal protection.
12.10.5 Verify through observation and review of processes that monitoring and responding to alerts from security monitoring systems are covered in the incident response plan.

alarmRule.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Compromise Alert Rule

commonEvent.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Compromise Alert Rule

name: PCI-DSS: DB Account Auth Failure Alert Rule
description: This AIE Rule alerts on the occurrence of any database authentication failure from unauthorized accounts in direct support of PCI-DSS controls 10.2.1, 10.2.4 and in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 8.7.a, 8.7.c-d.
details:
8.7.a Review database and application configuration settings and verify that all users are authenticated prior to access.
8.7.c Examine database access control settings and database application configuration settings to verify that user direct access to or queries of databases are restricted to database administrators.
8.7.d Examine database access control settings, database application configuration settings, and the related application IDs to verify that application IDs can only be used by the applications (and not by individual users or other processes).
10.2.1 Verify all individual access to cardholder data is logged.
10.2.4 Verify invalid logical access attempts are logged.

alarmRule.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: DB Account Auth Failure Alert Rule

commonEvent.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: DB Account Auth Failure Alert Rule

name: PCI-DSS: FW Policy Synch Failure Alert Rule
description: This AIE Rule alerts on the occurrence of any critical failure or error to firewall policy synchronization in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 1.2.2.a-b
details:
1.2.2.a Examine router configuration files to verify they are secured from unauthorized access.
1.2.2.b Examine router configurations to verify they are synchronizedfor example, the running (or active) configuration matches the start-up configuration (used when machines are booted).

alarmRule.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: FW Policy Synch Failure Alert Rule

commonEvent.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: FW Policy Synch Failure Alert Rule

name: PCI-DSS: Host Firewall Failure Alert Rule
description: This AIE Rule alerts on the occurrence of any critical failure or error to host firewalls in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 1.4.a
details:
1.4.a Examine policies and configuration standards to verify:
- Personal firewall software is required for all mobile and/or employee-owned devices that connect to the Internet when outside the network (for example, laptops used by employees), and which are also used to access the network.
- Specific configuration settings are defined for personal firewall software.
- Personal firewall software is configured to actively run.
- Personal firewall software is configured to not be alterable by users of mobile and/or employee-owned devices.

alarmRule.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Host Firewall Failure Alert Rule

commonEvent.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Host Firewall Failure Alert Rule

name: PCI-DSS: Invalid Act Auth Failure Alert Rule
description: This AIE Rule alerts on the occurrence of any authentication failure attempts from unauthorized accounts (default /disabled/terminated) in direct support of PCI-DSS Controls: 2.1.b/10.1/10.2.1-.2/10.2.4; supplemental support of 8.1.3.a/8.1.4/8.5.c
details:
2.1.a Choose a sample of system components, and attempt to log on (with system administrator help) to the devices and applications using default vendor-supplied accounts and passwords, to verify that ALL default passwords (including those on operating systems, software that provides security services, application and system accounts, POS terminals, and Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) community strings) have been changed. (Use vendor manuals and sources on the Internet to find vendor-supplied accounts/passwords.)
2.1.b For the sample of system components, verify that all unnecessary default accounts (including accounts used by operating systems, security software, applications, systems, POS terminals, SNMP, etc.) are removed or disabled.
8.1.3.a Select a sample of users terminated in the past six months, and review current user access listsfor both local and remote accessto verify that their IDs have been deactivated or removed from the access lists.
8.1.4 Observe user accounts to verify that any inactive accounts over 90 days old are either removed or disabled.
8.5.c Interview system administrators to verify that group and shared IDs and/or passwords or other authentication methods are not distributed, even if requested.
10.1 Verify, through observation and interviewing the system administrator, that:
- Audit trails are enabled and active for system components.
- Access to system components is linked to individual users.
10.2.1 Verify all individual access to cardholder data is logged.
10.2.2 Verify all actions taken by any individual with root or administrative privileges are logged.
10.2.4 Verify invalid logical access attempts are logged.

name: PCI-DSS: Malware Alert Rule
description: This AIE Rule alerts on the occurrence of any identified Malware event in direct support of PCI-DSS Controls: 5.2.d and in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 11.4.a-c, 12.10.5
details:
5.2.d Examine anti-virus configurations, including the master installation of the software and a sample of system components, to verify that:
- Anti-virus software log generation is enabled, and
- Logs are retained in accordance with PCI DSS Requirement 10.7.
11.4.a Examine system configurations and network diagrams to verify that techniques (such as intrusion-detection systems and/or intrusion-prevention systems) are in place to monitor all traffic:
- At the perimeter of the cardholder data environment
- At critical points in the cardholder data environment.
11.4.b Examine system configurations and interview responsible personnel to confirm intrusion-detection and/or intrusion-prevention techniques alert personnel of suspected compromises.
11.4.c Examine IDS/IPS configurations and vendor documentation to verify intrusion-detection and/or intrusion-prevention techniques are configured, maintained, and updated per vendor instructions to ensure optimal protection.
12.10.5 Verify through observation and review of processes that monitoring and responding to alerts from security monitoring systems are covered in the incident response plan.

commonEvent.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Malware Alert Rule

name: PCI-DSS: Physical Access Failure Alert Rule
description: This AIE Rule alerts on the occurrence of any critical failure or error to the physical access system in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 8.1.3.b, 9.1, 9.1.1.a, 9.1.2, 9.3.c,
details:
8.1.3.b Verify all physical authentication methodssuch as, smart cards, tokens, etc.have been returned or deactivated.
9.1 Verify the existence of physical security controls for each computer room, data center, and other physical areas with systems in the cardholder data environment.
- Verify that access is controlled with badge readers or other devices including authorized badges and lock and key.
- Observe a system administrators attempt to log into consoles for randomly selected systems in the cardholder environment and verify that they are locked to prevent unauthorized use.
9.1.1.a Verify that video cameras and/or access control mechanisms are in place to monitor the entry/exit points to sensitive areas.
9.1.2 Interview responsible personnel and observe locations of publicly accessible network jacks to verify that physical and/or logical controls are in place to restrict access to publicly accessible network jacks.
9.3.c Select a sample of recently terminated employees and review access control lists to verify the personnel do not have physical access to sensitive areas.

name: PCI-DSS: Priv Acct Auth Failure Alert Rule
description: This AIE Rule alerts on the occurrence of any authentication failure attempt from privileged accounts in direct support of PCI-DSS Controls: 10.1, 10.2.1, 10.2.2, 10.2.4, 10.2.5.a and augmented support of 7.1.1
details:
7.1.1 Select a sample of roles and verify access needs for each role are defined and include:
- System components and data resources that each role needs to access for their job function
- Identification of privilege necessary for each role to perform their job function.
10.1 Verify, through observation and interviewing the system administrator, that:
- Audit trails are enabled and active for system components.
- Access to system components is linked to individual users.
10.2.1 Verify all individual access to cardholder data is logged.
10.2.2 Verify all actions taken by any individual with root or administrative privileges are logged.
10.2.4 Verify invalid logical access attempts are logged.
10.2.5.a Verify use of identification and authentication mechanisms is logged.
