details:
11.4.a Examine system configurations and network diagrams to verify that techniques (such as intrusion-detection systems and/or intrusion-prevention systems) are in place to monitor all traffic:

name: PCI-DSS: Rogue WAP Detected Alert Rule
description: This AIE Rule alerts on the occurrence of any rogue access point detection events in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 11.1.b, 11.1.d, 12.10.5
details:
11.1.b Verify that the methodology is adequate to detect and identify any unauthorized wireless access points, including at least the following:
- WLAN cards inserted into system components
- Portable or mobile devices attached to system components to create a wireless access point (for example, by USB, etc.)
- Wireless devices attached to a network port or network device.
11.1.d If automated monitoring is utilized (for example, wireless IDS/IPS, NAC, etc.), verify the configuration will generate alerts to notify personnel.
12.10.5 Verify through observation and review of processes that monitoring and responding to alerts from security monitoring systems are covered in the incident response plan.

name: PCI-DSS: Software Update Failure Alert Rule
description: This AIE Rule alerts on the occurrence of software update failures in direct support of PCI-DSS Controls: 6.2.b
details:
6.2.b For a sample of system components and related software, compare the list of security patches installed on each system to the most recent vendor security-patch list, to verify the following:
- That applicable critical vendor-supplied security patches are installed within one month of release.
- All applicable vendor-supplied security patches are installed within an appropriate time frame (for example, within three months).

name: PCI-DSS: Vendor Account Enabled Alert Rule
description: This AIE Rule alerts on the occurrence of any access granting to vendor accounts in direct support of PCI-DSS controls: 10.2.1 and in supplemental support of PCI-DSS Controls: 8.1.5.a-b, 8.1.6.b & 12.3.9
details:
8.1.5.a Interview personnel and observe processes for managing accounts used by vendors to access, support, or maintain system components to verify that accounts used by vendors for remote access are:
- Disabled when not in use
- Enabled only when needed by the vendor, and disabled when not in use.
8.1.5.b Interview personnel and observe processes to verify that vendor remote access accounts are monitored while being used.
8.1.6.b Additional testing procedure for service provider assessments only: Review internal processes and customer/user documentation, and observe implemented processes to verify that non-consumer customer user accounts are temporarily locked-out after not more than six invalid access attempts.
10.2.1 Verify all individual access to cardholder data is logged.
12.3.9 Verify that the usage policies require activation of remote-access technologies used by vendors and business partners only when needed by vendors and business partners, with immediate deactivation after use.

name: NERC-CIP : Default Act Access Failure Rule
description: This AIE Rule provides details on default account access failure activity (failed object access/add/close/create/delete/download/execute/initialize/modify/move/read/rename/remove) within the organization infrastructure.
details:
5R3.2: Where technically feasible, the security monitoring process(es) shall detect and alert for attempts at or actual unauthorized accesses. These alerts shall provide for appropriate notification to designated response personnel. Where alerting is not technically feasible, the Responsible Entity shall review or otherwise assess access logs for attempts at or actual unauthorized accesses at least every ninety calendar days.
5R4.4: The Responsible Entity shall perform a cyber vulnerability assessment of the electronic access points to the Electronic Security Perimeter(s) at least annually. The vulnerability assessment shall include, at a minimum, a review of controls for default accounts, passwords, and network management community strings.
7R5.2: The Responsible Entity shall establish methods, processes, and procedures that generate logs of sufficient detail to create historical audit trails of individual user account access activity for a minimum of ninety days.
7R8.3:  The Responsible Entity shall perform a cyber vulnerability assessment of all Cyber Assets within the Electronic Security Perimeter at least annually. The vulnerability assessment shall include, at a minimum, a review of controls for default accounts.

name: NERC-CIP : ESP Allowed Ingress Comm Rule
description: This AIE Rule provides details on allowed ingress network communication to the ESP (electronic security perimeter).
details:
5R1.6: The Responsible Entity shall maintain documentation of Electronic Security Perimeter(s), all interconnected Critical and non-critical Cyber Assets within the Electronic Security Perimeter(s), all electronic access points to the Electronic Security Perimeter(s) and the Cyber Assets deployed for the access control and monitoring of these access points.
5R2.2: At all access points to the Electronic Security Perimeter(s), the Responsible Entity shall enable only ports and services required for operations and for monitoring Cyber Assets within the Electronic Security Perimeter, and shall document, individually or by specified grouping, the configuration of those ports and services.
5R2.4: Where external interactive access into the Electronic Security Perimeter has been enabled, the Responsible Entity shall implement strong procedural or technical controls at the access points to ensure authenticity of the accessing party, where technically feasible.
5R3: The Responsible Entity shall implement and document an electronic or manual process(es) for monitoring and logging access at access points to the Electronic Security Perimeter(s) twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week.
5R4.2: The vulnerability assessment shall include, at a minimum, a review to verify that only ports and services required for operations at these access points are enabled.
7R2: The Responsible Entity shall establish, document and implement a process to ensure that only those ports and services required for normal and emergency operations are enabled.
7R8.2: The Responsible Entity shall perform a cyber vulnerability assessment of all Cyber Assets within the Electronic Security Perimeter at least annually.

name: NERC-CIP : Account Disabled Rule
description: This AIE Rule provides details on account disabled within the organization infrastructure.
details:
3R5.2: The Responsible Entity shall review at least annually the access privileges to protected information to confirm that access privileges are correct and that they correspond with the Responsible Entitys needs and appropriate personnel roles and responsibilities.
4R4.1: The Responsible Entity shall review the list(s) of its personnel who have such access to Critical Cyber Assets quarterly, and update the list(s) within seven calendar days of any change of personnel with such access to Critical Cyber Assets, or any change in the access rights of such personnel. The Responsible Entity shall ensure access list(s) for contractors and service vendors are properly maintained.
4R4.2: The Responsible Entity shall revoke such access to Critical Cyber Assets within 24 hours for personnel terminated for cause and within seven calendar days for personnel who no longer require such access to Critical Cyber Assets.
7R5.2.1: The policy shall include the removal, disabling, or renaming of such accounts where possible. For such accounts that must remain enabled, passwords shall be changed prior to putting any system into service.

name: NERC-CIP : Account Locked Rule

details:
3R5.2: The Responsible Entity shall review at least annually the access privileges to protected information to confirm that access privileges are correct and that they correspond with the Responsible Entitys needs and appropriate personnel roles and responsibilities.
4R4.1: The Responsible Entity shall review the list(s) of its personnel who have such access to Critical Cyber Assets quarterly, and update the list(s) within seven calendar days of any change of personnel with such access to Critical Cyber Assets, or any change in the access rights of such personnel. The Responsible Entity shall ensure access list(s) for contractors and service vendors are properly maintained.

details:
3R5.2: The Responsible Entity shall review at least annually the access privileges to protected information to confirm that access privileges are correct and that they correspond with the Responsible Entitys needs and appropriate personnel roles and responsibilities.
4R4.1: The Responsible Entity shall review the list(s) of its personnel who have such access to Critical Cyber Assets quarterly, and update the list(s) within seven calendar days of any change of personnel with such access to Critical Cyber Assets, or any change in the access rights of such personnel. The Responsible Entity shall ensure access list(s) for contractors and service vendors are properly maintained.

name: NERC-CIP : Software Update Failure Rule
description: This AIE Rule provides details on software patching activity (software updated or software update failure) within the organization infrastructure.
details:
5R2.4: Where external interactive access into the Electronic Security Perimeter has been enabled, the Responsible Entity shall implement strong procedural or technical controls at the access points to ensure authenticity of the accessing party, where technically feasible.
7R1: The Responsible Entity shall ensure that new Cyber Assets and significant changes to existing Cyber Assets within the Electronic Security Perimeter do not adversely affect existing cyber security controls. For purposes of Standard CIP-007-4, a significant change shall, at a minimum, include implementation of security patches, cumulative service packs, vendor releases, and version upgrades of operating systems, applications, database platforms, or other third-party software or firmware.
7R3: The Responsible Entity, either separately or as a component of the documented configuration management process specified in CIP-003-4 Requirement R6, shall establish, document and implement a security patch management program for tracking, evaluating, testing, and installing applicable cyber security software patches for all Cyber Assets within the Electronic Security Perimeter(s).
7R3.2: The Responsible Entity shall document the implementation of security patches. In any case where the patch is not installed, the Responsible Entity shall document compensating measure(s) applied to mitigate risk exposure.

name: NERC-CIP : Suspicious Door Access Rule
description: This AIE Rule provides details on physical door access within the organization infrastructure.
details:
5R3.2: Where technically feasible, the security monitoring process(es) shall detect and alert for attempts at or actual unauthorized accesses. These alerts shall provide for appropriate notification to designated response personnel. Where alerting is not technically feasible, the Responsible Entity shall review or otherwise assess access logs for attempts at or actual unauthorized accesses at least every ninety calendar days.
6R1.3: The Responsible Entity shall document, implement, and maintain a physical security plan, approved by the senior manager or delegate(s) that shall address, at a minimum, processes, tools, and procedures to monitor physical access to the perimeter(s).
6R4: The Responsible Entity shall document and implement the operational and procedural controls to manage physical access at all access points to the Physical Security Perimeter(s) twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week. 
6R5: The Responsible Entity shall document and implement the technical and procedural controls for monitoring physical access at all access points to the Physical Security Perimeter(s) twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week. Unauthorized access attempts shall be reviewed immediately and handled in accordance with the procedures specified in Requirement CIP-008-4. 
6R6: Logging shall record sufficient information to uniquely identify individuals and the time of access twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week. The Responsible Entity shall implement and document the technical and procedural mechanisms for logging physical entry at all access points to the Physical Security Perimeter(s).

alarmRule.name: AIE: NERC-CIP: Suspicious Door Access Rule

commonEvent.name: AIE: NERC-CIP : Suspicious Door Access Rule

description: Measures the normal amount of outbound connections a host makes and generates an event when that amount increases.
details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP and Origin Application if its known, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN, block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Impacted IP Host and Application are known, add IP Impacted to block outbound and inbound on Firewall if unknown or add to Watch List for further assessment.

Configuration: In rule block 2, on the Log Source Critieria tab include filter, add List "Vulnerability Scanners" that LogRhythm is collecting from.

name: NIST 800-53 : Account Access Revoked Rule
description: This AIE Rule provides details on account access granting (access revoked, account disabled, account locked, account removed from group, ownership revoked, and privilege revoked).
details:
NIST 800-53 Requirements:
AC-2: The organization manages information system accounts, including:
AC-2.d: Specifies authorized users of the information system, group and role membership, and access authorizations (i.e., privileges) and other attributes (as required) for each account
AC-2.f: Creates, enables, modifies, disables, and removes information system accounts in accordance with [Assignment: organization-defined procedures or conditions]
AC-2.i: Authorizes access to the information system based on:
AC-2.i.1: A valid access authorization
AC-2.i.2: Intended system usage
AC-2.(1): The organization employs automated mechanisms to support the management of information system accounts.
AC-3: The information system enforces approved authorizations for logical access to information and system resources in accordance with applicable access control policies.
AC-5: The organization:
AC-5.a: Separates [Assignment: organization-defined duties of individuals]

name: NIST 800-53 : Antivirus Critical Condition Rule
description: This AIE Rule provides details on critical antivirus conditions.
details:
NIST 800-53 Requirements:
SI-3: The organization:
SI-3.a: Employs malicious code protection mechanisms at information system entry and exit points to detect and eradicate malicious code
SI-3.b: Updates malicious code protection mechanisms whenever new releases are available in accordance with organizational configuration management policy and procedures
SI-3.c: Configures malicious code protection mechanisms to:
SI-3.c.1: Perform periodic scans of the information system [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] and real-time scans of files from external sources at [Selection (one or more); endpoint; network entry/exit points] as the files are downloaded, opened, or executed in accordance with organizational security policy
SI-3.c.2: [Selection (one or more): block malicious code; quarantine malicious code; send alert to administrator; [Assignment: organization-defined action]] in response to malicious code detection
SI-3.(4): The information system updates malicious code protection mechanisms only when directed by a privileged user.
SI-4: The organization:
SI-4.a: Monitors the information system to detect:
SI-4.a.1: Attacks and indicators of potential attacks in accordance with [Assignment: organization-defined monitoring objectives]
SI-4.a 2: Unauthorized local, network, and remote connections
SI-4.b: Identifies unauthorized use of the information system through [Assignment: organization-defined techniques and methods]
SI-11: The information system:
SI-11.a: Generates error messages that provide information necessary for corrective actions without revealing information that could be exploited by adversaries
SI-11.b: Reveals error messages only to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles].

description: This AIE Rule provides details on multiple VPN authentication successes from the same origin login from different countries within a given time period (default 1 day).
details:
NIST 800-53 Requirements:
AC-17: The organization:
AC-17.a: Establishes and documents usage restrictions, configuration/connection requirements, and implementation guidance for each type of remote access allowed
AC-17.c: Monitors for unauthorized remote access to the information system
AC-17.(1): The information system monitors and controls remote access methods. 
CA-2: The organization:
CA-2.b: Assesses the security controls in the information system and its environment of operation [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] to determine the extent to which the controls are implemented correctly, operating as intended, and producing the desired outcome with respect to meeting established security requirements
CA-2.c: Produces a security assessment report that documents the results of the assessment
IR-5: The organization tracks and documents information system security incidents.

name: CSC: New Network Host
description: A new host is seen communicating in the environment for the first time. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 1.2
details:
Use Case : An attacker has cracked a company's internal wireless WPA2 key and has setup a rogue host to listen in promiscuous mode to all wireless traffic in the hopes of obtaining senstive information.

Required Configuration : 
(1) Be collecting from the LogRhythm Network Monitor.
(2) Define all internal network ranges. Then create an include filter in both the baseline and live period where Network (Origin) is <defined network ranges>
(3) In the Log Manager advanced properties turn on DNSIPToName resolution.

Optional Configuration: When turning on this rule for the first time, turn on suppression for 2 or 3 days. Then, after 2 or 3 days turn the suppression off again. This will allow data to build up in the baseline and alerts will become more accurate.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: New Network Host

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: New Network Host

name: Disruption: Distributed Denial of Service Attack
description: Excessive number of hosts communicating with a single host.
details:
Action: Investigate the Impacted IP and Impacted Application if its known, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN, block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Origin IP Host and Application are known and perform Incident Response on internal Origin IPs, or add to Watch List for further assessment.

Use Case: Attacker is using a botnet to attempt to take a public-facing service offline.

details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP and Origin Application if its known, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN, block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Impacted IP Host, Application and reputation are known, block the Impacted IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall if unknown or add to Watch List for further assessment.

Configuration: Authorized web applications need to have their ports added to the exclude filter list. 

Use Case: An unauthorized web service running inside a corporate network that hasn't been properly vetted and configured, has become compromised and is collecting employee credentials.

name: CSC: Malware Event

details:
Use Case: A user has browsed to a website hosting a drive-by attack and their corporate laptop is now infected, sending out phishing emails.


Optional Configuration: This rule can be useful without alarming in order to populate dashboards and reports. For more targeted real-time alarming it may be useful to add an include filter with a list of target hosts in the Impacted Host field.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Malware Event

description: Triggered when an internal host communicates with a host outside the network using a port not on the allowed list.   CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 9.2, CSC 12.1
details:
Use Case : A misconfigured firewall is allowing traffic to pass outside the network over the common VNC port (5900).

Configuration : The LogRhythm List "Allowed Egress Ports" must be populated for this rule to work.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Blacklisted Egress Port Observed

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Blacklisted Egress Port Observed

name: CSC: Blacklisted Ingress Port Observed
description: Triggered when an external host communicates with a network host on a port not on the allowed ingress list.  CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 9.2, CSC 12.1
details:
Use Case : A misconfigured firewall is allowing traffic to pass into the network on the common VNC port (5900).

Configuration : The LogRhythm List "Allowed Ingress Ports" must be populated for this rule to work.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Blacklisted Ingress Port Observed

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Blacklisted Ingress Port Observed

name: CSC: Multiple Passwords Modified by Different User
description: Multiple occurrences of one user changing another's password.  CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 16.14, CSC 5.1
details:
Use Case : A disgruntled employee is attempting to lock out multiple other users' accounts.

Required Configuration: The AI Engine rule "CSC: Password Modified by Another User" must be enabled. 
Optional Configuration: If IT personnel regularly reset multiple passwords this activity will likely set off this alarm. May need to exclude authorized users.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Multiple Passwords Modified by Different User

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Mult Pass Modified by Separate User

values.displayValue: AIE: CSC: Password Modified by Another User

name: CSC: External DNS Observed
description: Internal hosts using an external DNS server. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 12.1, CSC 12.8
details: Use Case: A network host has been infected with malware and is using a compromised external DNS server.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: External DNS Observed

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: External DNS Observed

name: CSC: Multiple Failed Access Attempts
description: User makes multiple failed access attempts within a short time period. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 16.6, CSC 5.1
details: Use Case: A new employee is exploring the file server looking for files they can access.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Multiple Failed Access Attempts

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Multiple Failed Access Attempts

name: CSC: Multiple Object Access Failures
description: Multiple users failed to access the same file. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 16.6, CSC 5.1
details: Use Case: A hacker has gained access to the network and is testing different accounts to see if one has access to a particular directory on the file server.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Multiple Object Access Failures

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Multiple Object Access Failures

name: CSC: New Wireless Host
description: A new host is seen communicating the environment for the first time. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 1.2, CSC 15.3
details:
Use Case : An attacker has cracked a company's internal wireless WPA2 key and has setup a rogue host to listen in promiscuous mode to all wireless traffic in the hopes of obtaining sensitive information.

Required Configuration : 
(1) Be collecting from the LogRhythm Network Monitor.
(2) Define all internal network ranges. Then create an include filter in both the baseline and live period where Network (Origin) is <defined network ranges>
(3) In the Log Manager advanced properties turn on DNSIPToName resolution.
(4) Populate the list Wireless Network IP Range

Optional Configuration: When turning on this rule for the first time, turn on suppression for 2 or 3 days. Then, after 2 or 3 days turn the suppression off again. This will allow data to build up in the baseline and alerts will become more accurate.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: New Wireless Host

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: New Wireless Host

name: CSC: Malware Not Cleaned
description: A malware removal event from a host followed immediately (within 1 hour) by another malware event. This indicates that the malware was not completely removed. CIS Critical Security Control(s): CSC 8.1
details: Use Case: A network host was infected with malware and the corporate virus scanner reported it cleaned. The malware was not fully removed and another malware event was seen shortly after.

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSC: Malware Not Cleaned

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSC: Malware Not Cleaned

name: Lateral: Password Modified by Admin
description:
Privileged user changes the password of another account.


CTD
details:
Action: Verify the change control procedure has been followed and that this user's password was reset according to standards and guidelines.

Optional Configuration : If you would like to exclude system accounts from this alarm, add an exclude filter for an Origin Login or Account which matches the regular expression '.*?/$'

alarmRule.name: AIE: Lateral: Password Modified by Admin

commonEvent.name: AIE: Lateral: Password Modified by Admin

name: Lateral: Admin Password Modified
description:
User changes the password of a different privileged user account.

CTD
details:
Action: Verify the admin was aware of the password change. Also verify change control procedure has been followed and that this user's password was reset according to standards and guidelines.

Optional Configuration : If you would like to exclude system accounts from this alarm, add an exclude filter for an Origin Login or Account which matches this regular expression: \$$

alarmRule.name: AIE: Lateral: Admin Password Modified

commonEvent.name: AIE: Lateral: Admin Password Modified

name: Account Anomaly: Disabled Admin Access Success
description:
Recently disabled or deleted privileged user account authenticates or accesses resources on the network

UTD
details:
Use Case: An employee is terminated or has left an organization.  Shortly after he/she is seen accessing network resources.

Optional Configuration : If using windows audit loggin make sure audit account management is turned on for successes and audit account logon events is turned on for success and failures in the local security policy.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Account Anomaly: Disabled Admin Access

commonEvent.name: AIE: Account Anomaly: Disabled Admin Access

name: Recon: Disabled Admin Access Failures
description:
Recently disabled or deleted privileged user account tries to authenticate or access resources on the network unsuccessfully.

UTD
details:
Use Case: An employee is terminated or has left an organization.  Shortly after he/she attempts to access network resources and does not succeed.

Optional Configuration : If using windows audit loggin make sure audit account management is turned on for successes and audit account logon events is turned on for success and failures in the local security policy.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Recon: Disabled Admin Access Failures

commonEvent.name: AIE: Recon: Disabled Admin Access Failures

name: C2: High Entropy Traffic
description: Network traffic which is considered to have a high level of entropy. This indicates that the traffic is encrypted but of an unknown protocol.
details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP and Origin Application if its known, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN, block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Impacted IP Host, Application and reputation are known, block the Impacted IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall if unknown or add to Watch List for further assessment.

Use Case: An infected network host is communicating with its command and control server using an unknown encrypted protocol.

alarmRule.name: AIE: C2: High Entropy Traffic

commonEvent.name: AIE: C2: High Entropy Traffic

name: C2: Port Misuse: 22
description: Traffic on port 22 that is not SSH
details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP and Origin Application if its known, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN, block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Impacted IP Host, Application and reputation are known, block the Impacted IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall if unknown or add to Watch List for further assessment.

Configuration:  Requires DNSIPToName resolution to be turned on in the mediator  Requires Network Monitor or similar.

Use Case: Detection of local hosts tunneling traffic over port 22. This would typically be a violation of network policy and a security risk.

alarmRule.name: AIE: C2: Port Misuse: 22

commonEvent.name: AIE: C2: Port Misuse: 22

name: C2: Port Misuse: 443
description: Traffic over port 443 that is not HTTPS.
details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP and Origin Application if its known, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN, block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Impacted IP Host, Application and reputation are known, block the Impacted IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall if unknown or add to Watch List for further assessment.

Configuration:  Requires DNSIPToName resolution to be turned on in the mediator  Requires Network Monitor or similar.

Use Case: Detection of local hosts tunneling traffic over port 443. This would typically be a violation of network policy and a security risk.

alarmRule.name: AIE: C2: Port Misuse: 443

commonEvent.name: AIE: C2: Port Misuse: 443

name: C2: Internationalized Domain Name (IDN)
description: Internationalized domain name (non-ASCII characters) in HTTP.
details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP and Origin Application if its known, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN, block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Impacted IP Host, Application and reputation are known, block the Impacted IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall if unknown or add to Watch List for further assessment.

Configuration: Since many Western organizations will see very limited use of IDNs, any usage may be deemed suspicious and possibly caused by malware. However, each organization can exclude legitimate domains to fit their environment.

Use Case: Black Hole Exploit kit, among others, uses internationalized domain names for hosting malware.

alarmRule.name: AIE: C2: Internationalized Domain Name (IDN)

commonEvent.name: AIE: C2: Internationalized Domain Name (IDN)

name: C2: Suspicious Top Level Domain (TLD)
description: HTTP traffic to TLDs that wouldn't be expected in most cases.
details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP and Origin Application if its known, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN, block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Impacted IP Host, Application and reputation are known, block the Impacted IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall if unknown or add to Watch List for further assessment.

Configuration:   Add an exclude filter List "Top Common Domains Using Suspicious TLDs" for the Group of domain names which are allowed in your environment.
Optional Configuration: Add an Impacted Host exclude filter List for Vulnerability Scanners, Mail Servers, perimeter devices, proxies, and AV servers in Rule Block 1.

Use Case: Malware beacons back to a .ru or other suspicious TLD.

alarmRule.name: AIE: C2: Suspicious Top Level Domain (TLD)

commonEvent.name: AIE: C2: Suspicious Top Level Domain (TLD)

value.name: Top Common Domains Using Suspicious TLDs

values.displayValue: Top Common Domains Using Suspicious TLDs

name: Honeypot: Activity
description:
Observed general honeypot interaction, wherein more than 10 interactions with the honeypot were triggered.

Modules:
Honeypot
details:
Use Case: This will track an attacker's interactions with multiple honeypots and will alert on any patterns observed from the same originating IP address. This is a great way to catch hackers attempting to break into real systems by serving up false systems and information to learn more about an adversary.

Configuration: In order to use this module, refer to the documentation to assure that at a minimum one of the currently supported honeypots has been implemented and configured properly.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Honeypot: Activity

commonEvent.name: AIE: Honeypot: Activity

name: Honeypot: Logon Failure
description:
Observed failed attacks on a honeypot login form.

Modules:
Honeypot
details:
Use Case: This rule will allow security analysts to detect failed attempts to breach their honeypot architectures, allowing them to begin tracking an attacker early and stopping them before they are able to attack real systems and gain access to sensitive information.

Configuration: In order to use this module, refer to the documentation to assure that at a minimum one of the currently supported honeypots has been implemented and configured properly.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Honeypot: Logon Failure

commonEvent.name: AIE: Honeypot: Logon Failure

name: Honeypot: Logon Success
description:
Observed successful attacks on a honeypot login form.

Modules:
Honeypot
details:
Use Case: This rule will allow security analysts to detect a successful breach of their honeypot architectures, allowing them to begin tracking an attacker early and stopping them before they are able to gain access to real systems and gain access to sensitive information.

Configuration: In order to use this module, refer to the documentation to assure that at a minimum one of the currently supported honeypots has been implemented and configured properly.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Honeypot: Logon Success

commonEvent.name: AIE: Honeypot: Logon Success

name: Honeypot: Host Compromise
description:
Observed successful attacks on a honeypot, resulting in gaining 'access' to the false system.

Modules:
Honeypot
details:
Use Case: This rule will allow security analysts to detect a successful breach of their honeypot architectures, allowing them to begin tracking an attacker early on, learn from their techniques, and stop them before they are able to gain access to real systems and gain access to sensitive information.

Configuration: In order to use this module, refer to the documentation to assure that at a minimum one of the currently supported honeypots has been implemented and configured properly.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Honeypot: Host Compromise

commonEvent.name: AIE: Honeypot: Host Compromise

name: Honeypot: Malware Activity
description:
Observed attempted/successful malware activity on the host.


Modules:
Honeypot
details:
Use Case: This rule will allow security analysts to detect attempted download / launching / subsequent malware usage following exploitation and system access. This rule allows analysts to learn from their techniques, capture malware, gather evidence, and stop them before they are able to gain access to real systems and steal sensitive information.

Configuration: In order to use this module, refer to the documentation to assure that at a minimum one of the currently supported honeypots has been implemented and configured properly.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Honeypot: Malware Activity

commonEvent.name: AIE: Honeypot: Malware Activity

name: Honeypot: Interaction
description:
Observed interaction in relation to high-interaction honeypots. This will help to capture and display pertinent activity related to hacking activity and further attempted exploitation of the server within the SIEM dashboard.

Modules:
Honeypot
details:
Use Case: This rule will allow security analysts to detect activities performed by the attacker following successful compromise. This rule allows analysts to learn from the attacker/bot techniques, capture malware, gather evidence, and stop them before they are able to gain access to real systems and steal sensitive information.

Configuration: In order to use this module, refer to the documentation to assure that at a minimum one of the currently supported honeypots has been implemented and configured properly.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Honeypot: Interaction

commonEvent.name: AIE: Honeypot: Interaction

name: Honeypot: Ongoing Attacker Activity
description:
Observed attacker interaction with a known honeypot followed by subsequent interaction with legitimate hosts within the environment, normally any publicly-facing services such as a production web server.

Modules:
Honeypot
details:
Use Case: This rule will allow security analysts to detect attackers probing legitimate resources following known interactions with a honeypot system. This allows analysts to see the activity and understand what other services they have targeted in addition to the honeypot. It also allows them to go back and understand if the attacker targeted other legitimate resources prior to interacting with the honeypot.

Configuration: In order to use this module, refer to the documentation to assure that at a minimum one of the currently supported honeypots has been implemented and configured properly.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Honeypot: Ongoing Attacker Activity

commonEvent.name: AIE: Honeypot: Ongoing Attacker Activity

name: Recon: Multiple Lockouts
description:
An account is locked out 2 or more times per hour.

UTD
CTD
details:
Action: Accounts under attack should be temporarily disabled while under investigation. Attack sources should be blocked via firewall or other security device. 

Use Case : In large companies it sometimes can be daunting and tedious to sift through the "noise" of potential operational events of interest. This alarm alerts when accounts are locked out 2 or more times in an hour instead of every time an account is locked out.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Recon: Multiple Lockouts

commonEvent.name: AIE: Recon: Multiple Lockouts

name: CSF: Account Access Revoked Rule
description: This AIE Rule provides details on account access granting (access revoked, account disabled, account locked, account removed from group, ownership revoked, and privilege revoked).
details:
CSF Requirements:
ID.AM-6: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for the entire workforce and third-party stakeholders (e.g., suppliers, customers, partners) are established
ID.GV-1: Organizational information security policy is established
ID.GV-2: Information security roles & responsibilities are coordinated and aligned with internal roles and external partners
ID.GV-3: Legal and regulatory requirements regarding cybersecurity, including privacy and civil liberties obligations, are understood and managed
PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are managed for authorized devices and users
PR.AC-4: Access permissions are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.AT-3: Third-party stakeholders (e.g., suppliers, customers, partners) understand roles & responsibilities
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented
PR.IP-1: A baseline configuration of information technology/industrial control systems is created and maintained
PR.IP-11: Cybersecurity is included in human resources practices (e.g., deprovisioning, personnel screening)
PR.PT-3: Access to systems and assets is controlled, incorporating the principle of least functionality
DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
DE.CM-3: Personnel activity is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
DE.CM-6: External service provider activity is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events

alarmRule.name: AIE: CSF: Account Access Revoked Rule

commonEvent.name: AIE: CSF: Account Access Revoked Rule

name: GPG-13: Time Sync Error
description: This AIE Rule creates an event and alerts for any time sync errors occurring on any Log Source Entities in direct support of GPG-13 control PMC1.2 [Alert A] and in supplemental support of PMC1.1 and 1.3.
details:
This AIE Rule is based on Data Segregation according to Log Source Root Entity and should be configured according to the entity structure.

GPG-13 Requirements:
PMC1.1 Each and every event record should include a simple time-stamp.
PMC1.2 Alert messages may reference related events and should also be time-stamped.
PMC1.3 Log file extracts should include an accurate time-stamp that is digitally signed.

alarmRule.name: AIE: GPG-13: Time Sync Error

GPG-13 Requirements:

name: GPG-13: Boundary Anti-Malware Policy Change
description: This AIE Rule creates an event and alerts on policy and configuration change logs from Anti-Malware software.
details:
This AIE Rule creates an event and alerts on policy and configuration change logs from Anti-Malware software.  This AIE Rule is not a direct requirement, but can be enabled to enhance the ability to track and respond to Anti-Malware policy and configuration changes and ensure changes are appropriate. 

This AIE Rule is based on Data Segregation according to Log Source Root Entity.

GPG-13 Requirements:
PMC2.2 Boundary Anti-Malware Plcy Change

name: Host Anomaly: Windows AppLocker Trigger
description:
Suspicious process was detected by AppLocker.

8003 - EXE/DLL detected but allowed
8004 - EXE/DLL not run
8006 - MSI/Script detected but allowed
8007 - MSI/Script not run

ETD
details:
AppLocker is Microsoft Windows inbuilt software restriction feature found in Windows 2008 onwards. This rule looks for Windows Event IDs relating to blocked execution of EXEs, DLLs, Scripts, or MSIs that could be unauthorized or malicious in nature.

8003 - EXE/DLL was allowed to run but would have been prevented from running if the AppLocker policy were enforced.
8004 - EXE/DLL was not allowed to run.
8006 - MSI/Script was allowed to run but would have been prevented from running if the 
8007 - MSI/Script was not allowed to run.

name: Compromise: PowerShell Reverse Shell
description:
Detects an insider attempting to establish a shell out of the organization using PowerShell on a compromised host, essentially opening a backdoor into the organization.

ETD
details:
Use Case : Detecting internal adversaries or compromised systems attempting to use PowerShell to shovel a shell to an external entity. Commonly used to backdoor systems and create an external entry point into the organization.

Required Configuration:
1) Add the organization's IP Address Range(s) to the include filter to avoid false-positives related to internal PowerShell use for system administration.

description:
Multiple unique external attack events against the same host.

ETD
NTD
details:

Optional Configuration: Create an Exclude Filter for Origin Host in Rule Block 1 where the Origin Host is the name of any vulnerability scanners.

name: C2: Attack then Outbound Connection
description:
An observed external attack or compromise followed by data leaving the system and going to the attacker.

CTD
details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP and Origin Application if its known, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN, block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Impacted IP Host, Application and reputation are known, block the Impacted IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall if unknown or add to Watch List for further assessment.

Use Case: An attacker is looking for sensitive financial information.  The attacker successfully compromises a host and is able to copy the information to the attacker's host.

alarmRule.name: AIE: C2: Attack then Outbound Connection

commonEvent.name: AIE: C2: Attack then Outbound Connection

name: Corruption: Audit Disabled by Admin
description:
Login by an administrator followed by disabling of an audit process.


CTD
details:
Action: If audits are being disabled, it is highly likely that malicious activity is taking place. Immediately launch LogRhythm investigations on the Log Source where this is occurring.

Use Case: A disgruntled administrator plans on malicious activity and disables auditing beforehand to ensure the activity isn't logged.

Configuration:  A include filter where Origin Login = list of privileged user ids must be entered into RB1.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Corruption: Audit Disabled by Admin

commonEvent.name: AIE: Corruption: Audit Disabled by Admin

name: Account Anomaly: Locally Created and Used
description:
An account is created on a host and then used shortly thereafter on the same host.

ETD
CTD
details:
Action: Local account creation is generally atypical in a corporate environment and can be used for malicious purposes. Investigate the local account to determine what it was used for. Run an investigation around the Origin User of the account creation activity to see if any other unusual activity is observed. 

Use Case:  A disgruntled administrator creates a dummy account to use temporarily while performing malicious activities in an attempt to mask who is performing the activity.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Account Anomaly: Locally Created and Used

commonEvent.name: AIE: Account Anomaly: Locally Created and Used

ETD
CTD
details:
Action: Investigate the Impacted Host of the lateral movement activity to determine if the exfiltration activity is related and if any other suspicious activity is present.

Use Case : An attacker is looking for sensitive financial information.  The attacker successfully compromises a host and is able to copy the information to a different external server.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: Lateral Movement then Exfil

commonEvent.name: AIE: Compromise: Lateral Movement then Exfil

name: Compromise: New Network Host
description: A new host is seen communicating in the environment for the first time.
details:
Action: Investigate the Origin IP and Origin Application if its known, quarantine unknown hosts to a Remediation VLAN, block the Origin IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall. Determine if Impacted IP Host, Application and reputation are known, block the Impacted IP from inbound and outbound on perimeter Firewall if unknown or add to Watch List for further assessment.

Configuration:   (1) Be collecting from the LogRhythm Network Monitor.  (2) Define all internal network ranges. Then create an include filter in both the baseline and live period where Network (Origin) is <defined network ranges>  (3) In the Log Manager advanced properties turn on DNSIPToName resolution. 

Optional Configuration: When turning on this rule for the first time, turn on suppression for 2 or 3 days. Then, after 2 or 3 days turn the suppression off again. This will allow data to build up in the baseline and alerts will become more accurate.

Use Case: An attacker has cracked a company's internal wireless WPA2 key and has setup a rogue host to listen in promiscuous mode to all wireless traffic in the hopes of obtaining senstive information.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Compromise: New Network Host

commonEvent.name: AIE: Compromise: New Network Host

name: Malware: Not Cleaned
description:
A malware removal event from a host followed immediately (within 1 hour) by another malware event. This indicates that the malware was not completely removed.

ETD
CTD
details:
Action: Many pieces of malware include complex persisitence mechanisms which may result in reinfection. Check antimalware system logs and investigate the impacted host to determine if the infection was successfully removed or if additional cleanup steps are required.

Use Case : A network host was infected with malware and the corporate virus scanner reported it cleaned. The malware was not fully removed and another malware event was seen shortly after.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Malware: Not Cleaned

commonEvent.name: AIE: Malware: Not Cleaned

name: Honeypot:: Honey Token
description: An observed access or related interaction with a honey token file.
details:
Use Case : Honey Token files have been placed throughout the organization in interesting places that would be prime locations for an attacker to access. These files serve as an early warning indicator to compromised insiders and lateral movement within the enterprise.

Configuration:  Honey Tokens should be deployed within the environment in accordance with the instructions included in the Deployment and User Guides. The 'Honeypot : Honey Token' list should be updated with all of the files and/or directories where Honey Tokens are located. Real Time File Integrity Monitoring needs to be enabled on the host(s) serving up the Honey Token files and a custom FIM policy needs to be in place, designating the files and directories that should be monitored with FIM.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Honeypot:: Honey Token

commonEvent.name: AIE: Honeypot: Honey Token

name: Malware: Double File Extension
description:
Detects files named to mask their true extension by adding a second extension in order to trick users who have 'hide known file extensions' enabled. For example, a file named filename.jpg.exe would appear as filename.jpg. 

ETD
details:
Tuning:
Some applications like Outlook generate .tmp files which may trigger this rule. Add an exclude filter for types of files which can be safely ignored such as "pst\.tmp".

alarmRule.name: AIE: Malware: Double File Extension

commonEvent.name: AIE: Malware: Double File Extension

name: Malware: RTLO File Name
description:
Detects file names which contain the Right-to-Left Override (RTLO) character followed by a pattern that indicates a file trying to hide its extension. 


ETD
details: Use Case: A user is sent a malicious file named "Application?fdp.exe" which is displayed in Windows as "Applicationexe.pdf" in order to trick the user into running a malicious executable.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Malware: RTLO File Name

commonEvent.name: AIE: Malware: RTLO File Name

name: ISO-27001: System Time Change After Compromise
description: This AIE rule creates an event every time an attack occurs within the environment, followed by a time change.
details:
ISO 27001 (2013) Requirements: 
A.12.4.4: The clocks of all relevant information processing systems within an organization or security domain shall be synchronized to a single reference time source.
A.12.5.1: The implementation of changes shall be controlled by the use of formal change control procedures.

alarmRule.name: AIE: ISO-27001: System Time Change After Compromise

commonEvent.name: AIE: ISO-27001: System Time Change After Compromis

name: ISO-27001: Data Exfiltration Rule
description: This AIE rule creates an event anytime an external attack or compromise occurs within the environment, followed by data leaving the same system.
details:
ISO 27001 (2013) Requirements:
A.13.1.1: Networks shall be adequately managed and controlled, in order to be protected from threats, and to maintain security for the systems and applications using the network, including information in transit.
A.13.2.1: Formal exchange policies, procedures, and controls shall be in place to protect the exchange of information through the use of all types of communication facilities.
A.13.2.3: Information involved in electronic messaging shall be appropriately protected.
A.14.1.1: Changes to systems within the development lifecycle shall be controlled by the use of formal change control procedures.
A.14.1.2:  Information involved in application services passing over public networks shall be protected from fraudulent activity, contract dispute and unauthorized disclosure and modification.
A:14.2.2:
A.14.2.3: When operating platforms are changed, business critical applications shall be reviewed and tested to ensure there is no adverse impact on organizational operations or security.
A.14.2.4: Modifications to software packages shall be discouraged, limited to necessary changes and all changes shall be strictly controlled.
A.18.1.3: Records shall be protected from loss, destruction, falsification, unauthorized access and unauthorized release, in accordance with legislatory, regulatory, contractual and business requirements.
A.18.1.4: Privacy and protection of personally identifiable information shall be ensured as required in relevant legislation and regulation where applicable.

name: ISO-27001: Data Loss Prevention Rule
description: This AIE Rule provides details of data generated by the LogRhythm Data Loss Defender.
details:
ISO 27001 (2013) Requirements:
A.13.1.1: Networks shall be adequately managed and controlled, in order to be protected from threats, and to maintain security for the systems and applications using the network, including information in transit.
A.13.2.1:  Formal exchange policies, procedures, and controls shall be in place to protect the exchange of information through the use of all types of communication facilities.
A.13.2.3: Information involved in electronic messaging shall be appropriately protected.
A.14.1.1: The information security related requirements shall be included in the requirements for new information systems or enhancements to existing information systems.
A.14.1.2:  Information involved in application services passing over public networks shall be protected from fraudulent activity, contract dispute and unauthorized disclosure and modification.
A.14.2.2: Changes to systems within the development lifecycle shall be controlled by the use of formal change control procedures.
A.14.2.3: When operating platforms are changed, business critical applications shall be reviewed and tested to ensure there is no adverse impact on organizational operations or security.
A.14.2.4: Modifications to software packages shall be discouraged, limited to necessary changes and all changes shall be strictly controlled.
A.18.1.3: Records shall be protected from loss, destruction, falsification, unauthorized access and unauthorized release, in accordance with legislatory, regulatory, contractual and business requirements.
A.18.1.4: Privacy and protection of personally identifiable information shall be ensured as required in relevant legislation and regulation where applicable.
A.8.3.1: Procedures shall be implemented for the management of removable media in accordance with the classification scheme adopted by the organization.

name: ISO-27001: Alarm on Malware Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates an event and alerts for any malware detection on any device that exists on the configured log source list or devices supporting network monitoring
details:
ISO 27001 (2013) Requirements:
A.12.2.1: Detection, prevention, and recovery controls to protect against malicious code and appropriate user awareness procedures shall be implemented.
A.12.4.1: Event logs recording user activities, exceptions, faults and information security events shall be produced, kept and regularly reviewed.
A.12.6.1: Timely information about technical vulnerabilities of information systems being used shall be obtained, the organization's exposure to such vulnerabilities evaluated, and appropriate measures taken to address the associated risk.
A.16.1.1: Management responsibilities and procedures shall be established to ensure a quick, effective and orderly response to information security incidents.
A.16.1.2: Information security events shall be reported through appropriate management channels as quickly as possible.
A.16.1.4: Information security events shall be assessed and it shall be decided if they are to be classified as information security incidents.
A.16.1.5: Information security incidents shall be responded to in accordance with the documented procedures.
A.16.1.6: Knowledge gained from analyzing and resolving information security incidents shall be used to reduce the likelihood or impact of future incidents.
A.16.1.7: The organization shall define and apply procedures for the identification, collection, acquisition and preservation of information, which can serve as evidence.
A.6.2.2: A policy and supporting security measures shall be implemented to protect information accessed, processed or stored at teleworking sites.

description: This AIE Rule creates an event and alerts for any blocked attempts to import or export files across the network parameter.
details:
ISO 27001 (2013) Requirements:
A.13.1.1: Networks shall be adequately managed and controlled, in order to be protected from threats, and to maintain security for the systems and applications using the network, including information in transit.
A.13.2.1: Formal exchange policies, procedures, and controls shall be in place to protect the exchange of information through the use of all types of communication facilities.
A.13.2.3: Information involved in electronic messaging shall be appropriately protected.

name: ISO-27001: Priv Act Access Failure Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates an alert and provides details on privileged account access failure activity (failed object access/add/close/create/delete/download/execute/initialize/modify/move/read/rename/remove).
details:
ISO 27001 (2013) Requirements:
A.12.4.3: System administrator and system operator activities shall be logged and the logs protected and regularly reviewed.
A.6.1.1: All information security responsibilities shall be defined and allocated. 
A.7.2.1: Management shall require all employees and contractors to apply information security in accordance with the established policies and procedures of the organization.
A.8.1.3: Rules for the acceptable use of information and of assets associated with information and information processing facilities shall be identified, documented and implemented.
A.9.1.2: Users shall only be provided with access to the network and network services that they have been specifically authorized to use.
A.9.2.1: A formal user registration and de-registration process shall be
implemented to enable assignment of access rights.
A.9.2.2: A formal user access provisioning process shall be implemented to assign or revoke access rights for all user types to all systems and services.
A.9.2.3: The allocation and use of privileged access rights shall be restricted and controlled.
A.9.4.1: Access to information and application system functions shall be restricted in accordance with the access control policy.
A.9.4.2: Where required by the access control policy, access to systems and applications shall be controlled by a secure log-on procedure.

name: ISO-27001: Term Act Access Failure
description: This AIE Rule creates an alert and provides details on terminated account access failure activity (failed object access/add/close/create/delete/download/execute/initialize/modify/move/read/rename/remove).
details:
ISO 27001 (2013) Requirements:
A.7.2.1: Management shall require all employees and contractors to apply information security in accordance with the established policies and procedures of the organization.
A.7.3.1: Information security responsibilities and duties that remain valid after termination or change of employment shall be defined, communicated to the employee or contractor and enforced.
A.8.1.3: Rules for the acceptable use of information and of assets associated with information and information processing facilities shall be identified, documented and implemented.
A.9.1.2: Users shall only be provided with access to the network and network services that they have been specifically authorized to use.
A.9.2.1: A formal user registration and de-registration process shall be implemented to enable assignment of access rights.
A.9.2.2: A formal user access provisioning process shall be implemented to assign or revoke access rights for all user types to all systems and services.
A.9.2.6: The access rights of all employees and external party users to information and information processing facilities shall be removed upon termination of their employment, contract or agreement, or adjusted upon change.
A.9.4.1: Access to information and application system functions shall be restricted in accordance with the access control policy.
A.9.4.2: Where required by the access control policy, access to systems and applications shall be controlled by a secure log-on procedure.

name: ISO-27001: Vendor Act Access Failure Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates an alert and provides detail on vendor account access failure activity (failed object access/add/close/create/delete/download/execute/initialize/modify/move/read/rename/remove).
details:
ISO 27001 (2013) Requirements:
A.14.2.7: The organization shall supervise and monitor the activity of outsourced system development.
A.15.1.1: Information security requirements for mitigating the risks associated with suppliers access to the organizations assets shall be agreed with the supplier and documented.
A.15.1.2:All relevant information security requirements shall be established and agreed with each supplier that may access, process, store, communicate, or provide IT infrastructure components for, the organizations information.
A.15.2.1: Organizations shall regularly monitor, review and audit supplier service delivery.
A.15.2.2:Changes to the provision of services by suppliers, including maintaining and improving existing information security policies, procedures and controls, shall be managed, taking account of the criticality of business information, systems and processes involved and re-assessment of risks.
A.7.2.1: Management shall require all employees and contractors to apply information security in accordance with the established policies and procedures of the organization.
A.8.1.3: Rules for the acceptable use of information and of assets associated with information and information processing facilities shall be identified, documented and implemented.
A.9.1.2: Users shall only be provided with access to the network and network services that they have been specifically authorized to use.
A.9.2.2: A formal user access provisioning process shall be implemented to assign or revoke access rights for all user types to all systems and services.
A.9.4.1: Access to information and application system functions shall be restricted in accordance with the access control policy.
A.9.4.2: Where required by the access control policy, access to systems and applications shall be controlled by a secure log-on procedure.

name: ISO-27001: Configuration or Policy Change
description: This AIE Rule creates an event and alerts on any change to any device configurations or policies within the defined environment.
details:
ISO 27001 (2013) Requirements:
A.12.1.2: Changes to the organization, business processes, information processing facilities and systems that affect information security shall be controlled.
A.12.2.1: Detection, prevention, and recovery controls to protect against malicious code and appropriate user awareness procedures shall be implemented.
A.12.4.1: Event logs recording user activities, exceptions, faults and information security events shall be produced, kept and regularly reviewed.
A.12.5.1: The implementation of changes shall be controlled by the use of formal change control procedures.
A.12.6.1: Timely information about technical vulnerabilities of information systems being used shall be obtained, the organization's exposure to such vulnerabilities evaluated, and appropriate measures taken to address the associated risk.
A.14.1.1: The information security related requirements shall be included in the requirements for new information systems or enhancements to existing information systems.
A.14.2.2: Changes to systems within the development lifecycle shall be controlled by the use of formal change control procedures.
A.14.2.3: When operating platforms are changed, business critical applications shall be reviewed and tested to ensure there is no adverse impact on organizational operations or security.
A.14.2.4: Modifications to software packages shall be discouraged, limited to necessary changes and all changes shall be strictly controlled.
A.16.1.1: Management responsibilities and procedures shall be established to ensure a quick, effective and orderly response to information security incidents.
A.16.1.2: Information security events shall be reported through appropriate management channels as quickly as possible.
A.16.1.4: Information security events shall be assessed and it shall be decided if they are to be classified as information security incidents.
A.16.1.5, A.16.1.6

A.12.3.1: Backup copies of information, software and system images shall be taken and tested regularly in accordance with an agreed backup policy.
A.12.4.1: Event logs recording user activities, exceptions, faults and information security events shall be produced, kept and regularly reviewed.
A.12.7.1: Audit requirements and activities involving checks on operational systems shall be carefully planned and agreed to minimize the risk of disruptions to business processes.
A.17.1.1: The organization shall determine its requirements for information security and the continuity of information security management in adverse situations, e.g. during a crisis or disaster.
A.17.2.1: Information processing facilities shall be implemented with redundancy sufficient to meet availability requirements.
A.18.1.3: Records shall be protected from loss, destruction, falsification, unauthorized access and unauthorized release, in accordance with legislatory, regulatory, contractual and business requirements.

name: ISO-27001: Software Status Change After Attack
description: This AIE Rule creates an event and alerts when a security event is followed by an application installation on the same host.
details:
ISO 27001 (2013) Requirements:
A.12.1.2: Changes to the organization, business processes, information processing facilities and systems that affect information security shall be controlled.
A.12.2.1: Detection, prevention, and recovery controls to protect against malicious code and appropriate user awareness procedures shall be implemented.
A.12.4.1: Event logs recording user activities, exceptions, faults and information security events shall be produced, kept and regularly reviewed.
A.12.5.1: The implementation of changes shall be controlled by the use of formal change control procedures.
A.12.6.1: Timely information about technical vulnerabilities of information systems being used shall be obtained, the organization's exposure to such vulnerabilities evaluated, and appropriate measures taken to address the associated risk.
A.12.6.2: Rules governing the installation of software by users shall be established and implemented.
A.14.1.1: The information security related requirements shall be included in the requirements for new information systems or enhancements to existing information systems.
A.14.2.2: Changes to systems within the development lifecycle shall be controlled by the use of formal change control procedures.
A.14.2.3: When operating platforms are changed, business critical applications shall be reviewed and tested to ensure there is no adverse impact on organizational operations or security.
A.14.2.4: Modifications to software packages shall be discouraged, limited to necessary changes and all changes shall be strictly controlled.
A.16.1.1: Management responsibilities and procedures shall be established to ensure a quick, effective and orderly response to information security incidents.
A.16.1.2: Information security events shall be reported through appropriate management channels as quickly as possible.
A.16.1.4, A.16.1.5, A.16.1.6, A.16.1.7, A.6.2.2

name: ISO-27001: Data Destruction Rule
description: This AIE rule creates an event anytime an external attack or compromise occurs within the environment, followed by a FIM delete or modify event on the same host.  Note that critical files must be monitored by LogRythm's FIM.
details:
ISO 27001 (2013) Requirements:
A.13.1.1: Networks shall be adequately managed and controlled, in order to be protected from threats, and to maintain security for the systems and applications using the network, including information in transit.
A.13.2.1: Formal exchange policies, procedures, and controls shall be in place to protect the exchange of information through the use of all types of communication facilities.
A.13.2.3: Information involved in electronic messaging shall be appropriately protected.
A.14.1.1: The information security related requirements shall be included in the requirements for new information systems or enhancements to existing information systems.
A.14.1.2:  Information involved in application services passing over public networks shall be protected from fraudulent activity, contract dispute and unauthorized disclosure and modification.
A.14.2.2: Changes to systems within the development lifecycle shall be controlled by the use of formal change control procedures.
A.14.2.3: When operating platforms are changed, business critical applications shall be reviewed and tested to ensure there is no adverse impact on organizational operations or security.
A.14.2.4: Modifications to software packages shall be discouraged, limited to necessary changes and all changes shall be strictly controlled.
A.18.1.3: Records shall be protected from loss, destruction, falsification, unauthorized access and unauthorized release, in accordance with legislatory, regulatory, contractual and business requirements.
A.18.1.4: Privacy and protection of personally identifiable information shall be ensured as required in relevant legislation and regulation where applicable.
A.8.3.1: Procedures shall be implemented for the management of removable media in accordance with the classification scheme adopted by the organization.

name: ISO-27001: Recent Disable Acct + Acs Fail
description: This AIE Rule creates an alert and provides details on recently disabled/deleted accounts failing to authenticate/access resources.
details:
ISO 27001 (2013) Requirements:
A.7.2.1: Management shall require all employees and contractors to apply information security in accordance with the established policies and procedures of the organization.
A.8.1.3: Rules for the acceptable use of information and of assets associated
with information and information processing facilities shall be identified, documented and implemented.
A.9.1.2: Users shall only be provided with access to the network and network services that they have been specifically authorized to use.
A.9.2.1: A formal user registration and de-registration process shall be implemented to enable assignment of access rights.
A.9.2.2: A formal user access provisioning process shall be implemented to
assign or revoke access rights for all user types to all systems and services.
A.9.2.4: The allocation of secret authentication information shall be controlled through a formal management process.
A.9.2.6: The access rights of all employees and external party users to information and information processing facilities shall be removed upon termination of their employment, contract or agreement, or adjusted upon change.
A.9.3.1: Users shall be required to follow the organizations practices in the use of secret authentication information.
A.9.4.1: Access to information and application system functions shall be restricted in accordance with the access control policy.
A.9.4.2: Where required by the access control policy, access to systems and applications shall be controlled by a secure log-on procedure.

Appropriate system monitoring agent settings should be configured for endpoint FIM monitoring based on the environment (Windows/Linux) to capture file path information.

A.14.2.4: Modifications to software packages shall be discouraged, limited to necessary changes and all changes shall be strictly controlled.
A.18.1.3: Records shall be protected from loss, destruction, falsification, unauthorized access and unauthorized release, in accordance with legislatory, regulatory, contractual and business requirements.

name: ISO-27001: VPN Node Registration Failure Rule
description: This AIE Rule creates an event and alerts on any unsuccessful Virtual Private Network (VPN) node registration attempt into the environment.
details:
ISO 27001 (2013) Requirements:
A.12.2.1: Detection, prevention, and recovery controls to protect against malicious code and appropriate user awareness procedures shall be implemented.
A.12.4.1: Event logs recording user activities, exceptions, faults and information security events shall be produced, kept and regularly reviewed.
A.12.6.1: Timely information about technical vulnerabilities of information systems being used shall be obtained, the organization's exposure to such vulnerabilities evaluated, and appropriate measures taken to address the associated risk.
A.13.1.1: Networks shall be adequately managed and controlled, in order to be protected from threats, and to maintain security for the systems and applications using the network, including information in transit.
A.16.1.2: Information security events shall be reported through appropriate management channels as quickly as possible.
A.16.1.4: Information security events shall be assessed and it shall be decided if they are to be classified as information security incidents.
A.16.1.5: Information security incidents shall be responded to in accordance with the documented procedures.
A.16.1.6: Knowledge gained from analyzing and resolving information security incidents shall be used to reduce the likelihood or impact of future incidents.
A.16.1.7: The organization shall define and apply procedures for the identification, collection, acquisition and preservation of information, which can serve as evidence.
A.6.2.2: A policy and supporting security measures shall be implemented to protect information accessed, processed or stored at teleworking sites.

name: GPG-13: VPN Node Registration Failure (un-Auth)
description: This AIE Rule creates an event and alerts on any unsuccessful Virtual Private Network (VPN) node registration attempt into the boundary by un-authorized users.
details:
This AIE Rule creates an event and alerts on any unsuccessful Virtual Private Network (VPN) node registration attempt into the boundary to supplement testing of GPG-13 control PMC6.2 [Alert A]. This rule specifically looks for un-authroized accounts, not listed within the GPG-13: Authroized VPN Users (list). This control and alert are also supplemented by other controls alerting on authentication failures [PMC3.3, 5.3, 6.1, 6.8]

This AIE Rule is based on Data Segregation according to Log Source Root Entity.

Configuration : Authorized web applications need to have their ports added to the exclude filter list.

Server unter Linux sowie Netzwerkkomponente drfen nicht den lteren und unsicheren TELNET-Protokoll zur Remoteschaltung benutzen, sondern den besseren und verschlsselten SSH-Protocol.

details: Use Case:  An attacker is attempting to setup the stickykeys expoloit, renaming sethc.exe to cmd.exe.

name: Host Anomaly: CMD Set As Debugger
description:
cmd.exe has been set as a debugger for the sethc.exe or utilman process. 

ETD
details: Use Case: An attacker is attempting to backdoor a host by using the stickykeys/utilman exploit, setting cmd.exe as a debugger for either of those processes. This allows an attacker to gain an elevated shell prior to logging into a host.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Host Anomaly: CMD Set As Debugger

commonEvent.name: AIE: Host Anomaly: CMD Set As Debugger

values.displayValue: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Windows NT\\CurrentVersion\\Image File Execution Options\\(sethc|utilman)\.exe (REGEX NO CASE)

name: PCI-DSS: Critical/Error Alert
description: This AIE Rule alerts on the occurrence of critical or error messages from a given host in supplemental support of PCI-DSS control: 6.5.5
details: 6.5.5 Examine software-development policies and procedures and interview responsible personnel to verify that improper error handling is addressed by coding techniques that do not leak information via error messages (for example, by returning generic rather than specific error details).

alarmRule.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Critical/Error Alert

commonEvent.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Critical/Error Alert

name: PCI-DSS: Vendor Act Access Fail Alert Rule
description: This AIE Rule alerts on vendor account access failure within the environment in direct support of PCI-DSS Controls: 10.2.1,10.2.4 and in supplemental support of controls: 8.1.5.b & 12.3.9
details:
8.1.5.b Interview personnel and observe processes to verify that vendor remote access accounts are monitored while being used.
10.2.1 Verify all individual access to cardholder data is logged.
10.2.4 Verify invalid logical access attempts are logged.
12.3.9 Verify that the usage policies require activation of remote-access technologies used by vendors and business partners only when needed by vendors and business partners, with immediate deactivation after use.

alarmRule.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Vendor Act Access Fail Alert Rule

commonEvent.name: AIE: PCI-DSS: Vendor Act Access Fail Alert Rule

name: PCI-DSS: Time Sync Error
description: This AIE Rule creates an event and alerts for any time sync errors occurring on any Log Source in supplemental support of PCI-DSS control: 10.4.2.b
details: 10.4.2.b Examine system configurations, time synchronization settings and logs, and processes to verify that any changes to time settings on critical systems are logged, monitored, and reviewed.

name: Progression: to Initial Compromise
description: Progression rules monitor for activity moving through the attack lifecycle. This alarm will fire when observed activity categorized as Reconnaissance and Planning is followed by Initial Compromise with the same user or host.
details: This rule looks for AIE Feedback events which move through the Attack Lifecycle stages. There will always be a Host (Impacted), Host (Origin), or User (Origin) in common. Drilling down on this alarm will return the AIE events which triggered it. Drill down on those events to return the underlying log data. Run an investigation for the User or Host specified to look for related activity.

alarmRule.name: AIE: Progression: to Initial Compromise

commonEvent.name: AIE: Progression: to Initial Compromise

name: LR AI Cloud: High User Anomaly Score
description: This rule examines LogRhythm UEBA events and alarms when a user reaches a threshold score (85 by default).
details:
AI Cloud rules are populated by the LogRhythm AI Cloud service to identify anomalous user activity based on a number of indicators. LogRhythm AI Cloud data is required for this AI Engine rule - for more information please contact your Customer Relationship Manager. 

When this rule fires, you can copy the URL in the Session field to examine data in the LogRhythm UEBA web interface. You can also pivot on the impacted user to examine the user's activity. Be aware that the alarm time is not necessarily when the suspicious activity occurred, so investigations/pivots should be run to include 24-48 hours prior to the UEBA event.

alarmRule.name: AIE: LR AI Cloud: High User Anomaly Score

commonEvent.name: AIE: LR AI Cloud: High User Anomaly Score
